investigation_findings: On March 11, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Shakisha Henry, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the revised finding for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed one staff and one youth in person in the facility and conducted telephone interview with County Social Worker (CSW2) on 12/12/24, LPA conducted telephone interivew with County Social Worker (CSW) on 12/19/24, LPA conducted telephone interviews with three staff and interviewed one minor in person on 02/25/25 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated March 11, 2025). LPA also reviewed documents including but not limited to Client's Need and Service Plans, Special Incident Reports (SIR), client's notes, law enforcement report and other documents. It was alleged Staff spoke inappropriately to youth.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Maria Luna at Bella Vista Maple because no one was available at the Evergreen location. The purpose was to finalize this complaint investigation. LPA arrived at the Maple St. location at 12:30 PM after having been to the Evergreen location at 12:00 PM. On July 19, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward received an emailed copy of a clearance letter from a company named Mold Inspection & Testing. The letter indicated that professional mold remediation was not required. LPA Jones-Steward contacted the technician who issued the letter for clarification. The technician informed LPA Jones-Steward that mold was found at the home. However the level of mold was not enough to presentt an immediate health hazard. The technician stated that he had verbally advised the administrator to enlist a prfessional HVAC cleaner to remove the mold that did exist. Based on consultation with the technician who inspected the home, the allegation that mold was found in the home was substantiated. A finding that the complaint is substantiated means that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed the administrator, facility manager, direct care staff and the police officer who witnessed the reported allegations. LPA also reviewed the client's most recent individualized personal plan (IPP) and the schedule for the date of the incident. LPA found that there was only one staff person on duty during the time of the AWOL. However based on the client's IPP, she had AWOLED several times in a 6 month period and was prone to agressive and assaultive behavior. Her AWOL frequency and violent behavior were indicative of a need for increased supervision. Based on the available information, the above allegations are resolved as substantiated. Substantiated means that there is a preponderance of evidence that the allegation true. Facility was cited under 80078(a) Responsibility To Provide Care and Supervision
deficiency_1_description:
Responsibility to provide care & supervision
The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a written plan to detail how supervision will be based on client needs and behaviors as well as regulatory ratios.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with administrator Shakisha Henry to resolve the above allegations. The allegations were initially discussed with former administrator Teandra Potts. Per Ms Henry and Ms. Potts there were miscommunications that led to C1 being sent to school without a sufficient supply of diapers or clothing changes. Ms. Henry also admitted that a former employee had ruined the clothing of C1 by using too much bleach in the wash. On the date of inspection, LPA reviewed the clothing of C1 and found that the ruined clothing had been replaced by clothing in good condition. LPA ws not able to reach school personnel, but both the mother and regional center coordinator for C1 agreed that he was no longer being sent to school eith insufficient clothing. Based on the investigation, interviews and review of C1's file the above allegations were found to be substantiated. A substantiated finding means that the â€œpreponderance of the evidenceâ€ standard has been met. The facility was cited under Title 22 Section 80078(a).

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA reviewed client records and interviewed staff, behavioral consultants, regional center coordinators and parents, LPA also made personal observations of the suprvision being provided to clients on two separate visits. Based on the records reviews, interviews and personal observations, it was determined that Bella Vista Wyoming has not been providing the supervision that is necessitated by the clients needs and required by the regional center. LPA has personally observed the facility to not adhere to the ratios required by regional center. LPA has also been advised by several witnesses that the facility is frequently in violation of the said ratios, Therefore the allegation is substantiated A substantiated finding means that there is a preponderance of evidence that an allegation did occur.

investigation_findings: This report is being Amended from the original dated 12/12/2022 in order to correct the citation type on the 9099D page. LPA spoke with Administrator, Lavatha Oliver. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties, reviewed records, and gathered documentation. Confidential interviews and records produced corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Staff interviews reveal that staff handled client in a rough manner while performing a one-man restraint causing the client injuries. As a result, the staff was terminated from service. Client interview reveal that staff pushed client and injured the clientâ€™s neck. Based on information obtained, the allegation is Substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5. investigation_findings: On August 23, 2021 at 1:00 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Boys Hope/Girls Hope Program House Manager Chelsea Breckenridge to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigation Branch Special Investigator (SI) Annette Renquist. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On June 4, 2021 Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging Staff member (Staff #1 [S1]) sexually abused group home child (Child #1 [C1]). Specifically, it was reported between August 2020 and February 2021, S1 would touch C1 inappropriately while in the facility and while being transported. Additionally, it was reported on at least two occasions S1 took C1 from the facility in the middle of the night ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

investigation_findings: This is an amended report On June 25, 2022 at 11:00 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard met with Lupe Rodriguez to deliver findings on the above allegation(s). Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez and Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted the investigation into the above allegations. LPA Hernandez conducted the initial 10-day complaint inspection on February 25, 2022 and conducted confidential interviews with three staff. AGPA Woodard conducted subsequent visits to the facility on April 8, 2022 and May 20, 2022; confidential interviews were conducted with three staff members, and one client. Additional phone interviews were conducted on May 20th, 21st, and June 15th, 2022. Confidential interviews revealed that there are two staff present for each shift, including NOC. The day of the incident there were two staff on shift. While staff person was being attacked by four clients, one client blindsided staff and punched staff in the face. In return, Staff punched one of the boyâ€™s in their chest who was not the alleged victim. In interview with the minor who was punched in the chest, minor didnâ€™t disclose the attack against staff or that he was punched by staff but referenced another staff member who swung on the alleged victim. The alleged victim has a history of verbally going after staff as well as physically assaulting staff and people in the community. After staff didnâ€™t receive any support from other staff member at the facility, staff gathered his items and left the facility to report the incident to the police, leaving the staff person with five clients temporarily until additional staff arrived. Based on confidential interviews and review of supportive documentation, the Staff member admitted to hitting a minor in self-defense when he was being attacked by four minors, and leaving the facility to report it with Law Enforcement, which left one staff alone with five clients, therefore the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the personal rights and lack of supervision allegations are substantiated. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing standars (ILS), the following deficiencies are cited. (See LIC9099-D) A copy of this report was left, and appeal rights were discussed

investigation_findings: On 7/1/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the residential treatment group home facility to deliver findings of an investigation of the above allegation, which was conducted by the Licensing Agency's Investigations Branch (IB). LPA met with Mental Health Technician Latiesha O'Neal and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, an overnight staff member would kiss a client on the forehead when helping the client to bed and took another client out of their bedroom on their 18th birthday, kissed the client, and touched the client's buttocks, vagina, and breasts. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072 Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Mental Health Technician Latiesha O'Neal, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: On 9/16/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and Interim Administrator Virginia Parish and informed of the purpose of the visit. The investigation was conducted the Licensing agency's Investigations Branch (IB). During investigation, relevant record review, including medical records and police report, and confidential interviews with involved parties were conducted. Based on record review and confidential interviews, a resident was sexually assaulted by another resident with whom they shared a bedroom during the night. Staff on the overnight shift did not conduct room checks between 12:35AM and 2:20AM, and when the victim reported the incident to staff, staff did not respond by reporting the incident to police or facility management staff. The resident was offered to sleep in another room but was permitted to return to sleep in the bedroom. The resident sustained bruising as a result of the incident. Additionally, based on confidential interviews, a resident was sexually assaulted by another resident, and staff did not witness incident due to being on their phone.
met_with: Administrator Sara Stokes; Interim Administrator Virginia Parish

investigation_findings: On 11/04/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a follow up complaint inspection and met with Administrator Britney Gay. Residents were interviewed and were consistent in stating that they were meeting in the hallway to kiss each other or entering rooms prior to bedtime without staff knowledge. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that there was a lack of supervision that resulted in inappropriate behaviors between residents. investigation_findings: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conversed via phone with Administrator Noel Camatog regarding a complaint investigation at the facility. The purpose of the conversation was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. Due to current COVID-19 protocols, this visit was conducted over the phone and the appropriate signatures will be acquired subsequently. During the course of the investigation, LPA Bertoli inspected the Group Home facility (virtually), interviewed staff, teachers, Regional Center staff, and Parent, and reviewed documentation. LPA confirmed through records and interview with Administrator Camatog that although the facility had a signed Consent for Emergency Medical Treatment (LIC627B), they did not have an authorization on file for non-emergency medical care. Regulations require consent forms for both circumstances, but facility was utilizing the "RECORDS TO BE MAINTAINED BY THE FACILITY â€“ GROUP HOMES" (LIC311B), which is currently available on the CCL website, and only lists the LIC627B as being required. (continued on 9099-C)

investigation_findings: On 9/14/21 at 3:11PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Liza Tagpis and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation pertains to an incident of inappropriate sexual behavior in which resident R1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) made a sexual advance towards R2 and engaged in inappropriate touching. R2 said "no" to R1 and left. Based on staff reports, staff present at the facility were downstairs, and the residents were upstairs and meant to be in their rooms to be falling asleep. R1 initially denied the incident happened and then admitted to staff it did. Based on interviews, a similar incident has occured at least once prior, and similar incidents involving other residents have occured at this facility and it's sister facility also managed by Licensee and managed by the same Co-Administrators. Additionally, reports indicate that youth also would have preferred greater supervision and felt that staff believed one youth over the other, which could have been prevented if staff were present to witness the incident themselves. Based on interviews, enhanced supervision was needed in order to prevent additional...

On 12/22/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings for the above allegation. LPA met with Supervisor Edwin Isip and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility was unaware that a resident in care had a history of seizure activity. The resident last had a seizure at 9 years old, approximately 7 years ago. This is not documented in the resident's care plan and was only learned after a staff member witnessed the seizure and the facility notified a family member, who informed the facility of the previous seizure. The staff who witnessed the incident, which occurred around 5AM, responded to the sound of the resident falling off the bed and upon observing the resident shaking, turned the resident's head, and observed the resident until they stopped shaking after about 2 minutes, at which point the resident was able to get up and lie down on their bed. Due to believing it to not be critical, the staff member did not call 911. The staff shortly after called facility management, and when Facility Manager arrived... [CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE]

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility to inform them of the findings for the above listed allegation. LPA met with Daniel Padron Garcia, Site superviser (SS) at 1:45 PM on 6/7/23. LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documents during this investigation. During interviews with individuals invovled it was determined that the facility at times was operating out of ratio due to a staff shortage. There were times where there was only one staff member watching six clients. This lead to some of the individuals' needs not being met.Things individuals could do were limited due to not having enough staff to provide supervision for everyone. Based on interviews and documents review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above listed allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. As a result of this visit, there is one General Licensing Standards 80065 Personnel Requirements violation (80065(a)) an one General Licensing Standards 80022 Plan of Operation (80022(k)).The facility will be cited. Appeal rights were discussed and provided to ED. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Daniel Padron Garcia, SS whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents (POC will be made on a different day due to Admin being ill).

investigation_findings: On 3/19/2024 at 9:38 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Mona Lam, conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to inform the facility representative of the findings for the allegations above. LPA met with Alyssa Avila who assisted with the inspection. Based on confidential interviews conducted and supportive documentation to include but not limit repair receipts. The facility grounds has a septic tank that became backed up and the plumbing in the facility was not able to be used. Clients needed to use the restrooms in the main office next door. Facility also has a broken dryer and the dryer used to dry clients clothing is in the office next door. Facility maintenance person responded and the septic tank was worked on for at least two days. Technical advisory issued. Based on confidential interviews and a review of supportive documentation to include but not limit staff schedule and program plan of operation, the facility was operating outside of the required operating ratio according to plan of operation. Based on confidential interviews administrator and supervisors did not respond to crisis situations when called on for support as outlined in the plan of operation emergency intervention plan.

investigation_findings: On 8/27/2024 at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Kristin Pierotti, conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this inspection is to inform the facility representative of the findings for the complaint investigation regarding the allegations above. Facility manager Arianna Mendoza assisted with the inspection. Based on confidential interviews, obtained documentation to include but do not limit, staff communication, medication records, and staff schedules. Facility is cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Sections 80022(k) Plan of Operation as described on the following page LIC9099D. facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility to inform them of the findings for the above listed allegation. LPA met with Daniel Padron Garcia, Site superviser (SS) at 1:45 PM on 6/7/23. LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documents during this investigation. During interviews with individuals invovled it was determined that the facility at times was operating out of ratio due to a staff shortage. There were times where there was only one staff member watching six clients. This lead to some of the individuals' needs not being met.Things individuals could do were limited due to not having enough staff to provide supervision for everyone. Based on interviews and documents review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above listed allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. As a result of this visit, there is one General Licensing Standards 80065 Personnel Requirements violation (80065(a)) an one General Licensing Standards 80022 Plan of Operation (80022(k)).The facility will be cited. Appeal rights were discussed and provided to ED. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Daniel Padron Garcia, SS whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents (POC will be made on a different day due to Admin being ill).

The purpose of this inspection is to deliver the findings for the above allegations. LPA's met with administrator Princess Garcia who assisted with the inspection. Based on LPAâ€™s observations, conducted confidential interviews, and supportive documentation to include but not limit, incident reports. There were more than 10 incident reports and a minimum of five that were law enforcement contact, that were not reported to the department. It was also determined that during the evening hours of operation there is not facility manager on site while clients are in care. Facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84061(i) Reporting Requirements and 84065.2(a)(1)(A)(3) Personnel Duties as outlined on the following 9099 D. investigation_findings: On February 19, 2025 at 6 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, conducted a follow-up inspection to the facility for the purpose of delivering an amended Complaint Investigation Report regarding the finding on the complaint and to issue a citation. The LPA met with Kanetra Bolden, Facility Manager. On October 14, 2024, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: Client (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated February 6, 2025) at the facility on October 17, 2024; Administrator, Gina Sardano, via telephone on January 31, 2025; a Facility Manager, Ref. #2, via telephone on February 3, 2025; and the County Social Worker (CSW) via telephone on February 5, 2025. The LPA reviewed the incident reports, Ref. #1's Case Plan and police report. The investigation revealed that the facility denied the allegation. It revealed that the facility provided MPCRP a Law Enforcement Contact Report on October 13, 2024 and reported to the CSW the date the incident happened.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Inouye conducted a follow up complaint inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Emily Logan . The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA conducted interviews and reviewed documentation. Based on the findings, Staff#1 performed a manuel restraint on client #1. Due to the size ratio of staff and client a manuel restraint was not appropriate to ensure the safety of the client. During the manuel restraint staff #2 assisted in a 2 person hold which ensured everyones safety. Based on the information that was gathered, there is a preponderance of evidence that initial assessment and staffing was not appropriate for the needs of the clientel when emergency interventions are required. Appropriate staffing for emergency interventions was not available and clients that was restrained were potientially subject to injury. Facility cited for violation of General Regulations 870078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Inouye conducted a follow up complaint inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) 2nd Home - Sample and met with Emily Logan. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA conducted interviews and reviewed documentation. Based on the findings, Staff #1 did act inappropriately with client #1. During supervision, client #1 approached Staff #1. Staff #1 inappropriately used a disengagement technique and used a pen to create personal space. Staff #1 made contact (with the Pen) with Client #1 which caused a bruise on the abdomen. investigation_findings: On February 24, 2021 at 9:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an announce telephone call the above said facility, for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and to deliver the findings. After reviewing all the statements and the information obtained, the above allegation is substantiated, because the confidential interviews confirmed that there was a physical fight between the clients at the facility. When the fight started between C1 and C2, staff (S4) went to the second floor to grab the phone, leaving the other staff (S5) alone while C2 was on top of C1 hitting her and pulling her hair. investigation_findings: On 12/14/22 at 10:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy Oâ€™Connell made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the finding. LPA spoke with Marylou Escoto and together, discussed the investigative finding. On 8/2/22, the department received a complaint alledging that a minor engaged in inappropriate contact with another minor. During the investigative process, LPA Oâ€™Connell conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information on the above allegation. After reviewing all the statements and the information obtained, the above allegation is supported, as the confidential interviews confirmed that C2 has demonstrated a history of inappropriate behaviors that necessitate the provision of additional supervision to ensure the safety of C2 and other residents in care. Further record reviews show that the placing agency authorized the provision of one to one supervision for C2 on 6/6/22, and was backdated to 5/23/22 due to the licensee confirming that one to one services had already begun in order to â€œensure the safety of the client and assist with her stabilization.â€ Further confidential interviews, and record reviews revealed that C2 has not been assigned a one to one staff on a consistent basis, and in alignment with the authorization from the placing agency, thereby leading to opportunities for the minor to engage in aggressive and inappropriate behaviors with other residents. Based on LPAs observations, record reviews and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Based on California Code of Regulations, and Interim licensing Standards (ILS), a deficiency is being cited at this time. See 9099D for details.
deficiency_1_description:
87078(b) the licensee shall provide services identifies in each childâ€™s or nonminor dependents needs and services planâ€¦.. as necessary to meet the childs and nonminor dependents needs...
This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee will develop a plan to provide one on one coverage for C2 based on the hours authorized by the Dept. of CHildren and Family Services. Licensee will document services provided to reflect consistent supervision and efforts to decrease target behaviors. Licensee will make records related to one on one services availabel to DCFS and CCLD upon request. One on one services are to be provided as a stand alone service and staff are not to perform program duties when providing one one one services for residents.

investigation_findings: On April 4, 2023 at 9:10am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy Oâ€™Connell made unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility for the purpose of conducting an initial investigation on the above allegation. On June 28,2023 at1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy Oâ€™Connell made unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA Oâ€™Connell met with Marylou Escoto and discussed the investigative findings. On 3/16/23, the Department received a complaint alleging staff are not trained. During the investigative process, LPA Oâ€™Connell conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information on the above allegations. After reviewing all the statements and the information obtained, the above allegation is supported, as the confidential interviews confirmed that primary residential counselors, responsible for the direct care of clients, are not afforded with necessary training to manage symptoms/behaviors presented by target population that the program serves. Further confidential interviews revealed that staff have not been provided with comprehensive and completed ProAct training, which is used for the purpose of de-escalation, redirection, and conceptualization of trauma based behaviors. This training and training of a similar nature provide staff with the tools to administer trauma-informed care, and support client/staff safety. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, Division & Chapter number), are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: On 11/10/2021, at 12:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an announce inspection at the above said facility, and met with Breanna McCormick Facility Administrator (FA), who granted access into the facility. investigation_findings: On 7/27/23 at 10:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy Oâ€™Connell made unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility for the purpose of conducting an investigation on the above allegation and deliver the finding. LPA Oâ€™Connell met with the facility administrator and discussed the investigative finding. On 7-20-23, the Department received a complaint alleging that a client was dragged out of a bedroom. During the investigative process, LPA Oâ€™Connell conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information on the above allegation. After reviewing all the statements and the information obtained, the above allegation is supported, as the confidential interviews confirmed that S1 and S2 removed C3 from bedroom #1 against her will, while C3 was on top of a mattress. Evidence obtained includes video footage showing C3 being forcibly moved out of the bedroom by S2. Further confidential interviews revealed that interventions used to remove C3 from bedroom #1 are not approved behavioral redirection/intervention techniques utilized by the program. Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted, along with record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. investigation_findings: On 10/29/21 at 3PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver invesitgation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Patricia McCorkell and informed of purpose of visit. Based on report, the complaint was regarding an incident in which the resident was left unattended at the hospital. Based on confidential interviews with staff, resident, and witnesses, resident R1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) was left unattended at the hospital and, during this stay, was administered medication without the hospital obtaining appropriate consent from authorized representatives. Staff statements contradict, but no staff witnessed staff S1, who was delegated to supervise R1, go to the hospital, following R1 in the ambulance. R1's authorized representative notified staff S3 that R1 was unattended at the hospital and that the hospital had no contact for the facility. S3 called the facility and spoke to S1 and informed S1 at that time that S1 needed to be at the hospital with R1. S3 went to hospital, supervised R1, and transported back to facility after discharge. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. LPA issued a citation per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Section 87065.2 Personnel Duties. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Facility Manager Patricia McCorkell.
deficiency_1_description:
87065.2 Personnel Duties
(b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups... (8) Any other duties that may be necessary to ensure the health and safety of children in the facility.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to hold an all-staff training on emergency protocols for when a resident is transported to the hospital by emergency services.  Supervision should be maintained as appropriate and staff should ensure the correct hospital has the resident's medical information and facility/staff contact information.

investigation_findings: On 10/29/21 at 1:54PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Patricia McCorkell and informed of the purpose of visit. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with residents, staff, and witnesses. Based on report, the allegation pertains to staff having an inappropriate tone and attitude toward residents. Based on confidential interviews, staff have used a rough tone and inappropriate language when directing youth to get off of the phone and when redirecting youth. Multiple staff stated they heard staff using a rough tone that was not appropriate or not conducive to work in this type of facility and/or that they did not agree with being used in interactions with residents. Additionally, LPA observed multiple staff to have an unsupportive tone when discussing resident behaviors that was significant enough to make LPA concerned about that carrying over to interactions with residents. Staff expressed their frustrations and disbelief in residents' condition(s), at times in earshot of residents, which is inappropriate. Statements also indicate that residents feel staff pick favorites among the residents, evidenced by staff leaving out some residents in conversations or day to day activities, like calling residents down for meals.
deficiency_1_description:
87072 Personal Rights
(d)(10) To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit no later than COB Tuesday 11/02/21:  a detailed plan, with dates, to have all staff attend training(s) on personal rights, trauma-informed care, preventing favoritism, using a gentle tone, and the medical/physical impacts of trauma, including physiological and psychological conditions.

investigation_findings: On 7/7/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Patricia McCorkell and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, body searches and room searches are conducted with consent, but not all residents were aware that their consent is needed. Interviews revealed that residents are not touched during searches and only outerwear is requested to be removed, but at least two body searches consisted of a resident being requested to shake out their bra. Interviews also indicated that some staff were more consistent with searches than others and that there is no written search policy. A review of the program statement revealed no written search policies. There is also no documentation or log of searches conducted. With no policy and no documentation of searches, it is not clear that the facility is consistent with body search procedures nor that such procedures have been approved by the licensing agency.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit a revised program statement or addendum with body and room search procedures for CCL review by end of day on due date.

investigation_findings: On 1/18/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit at the facility in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Patricia McCorkell and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review, there have been multiple observations of staff speaking disrespectfully to residents in care, and there have been multiple instances of allowance being withheld. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87072 Personal Rights. investigation_findings: On 10/04/22 at 2:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Torres met with Veronica Manzo, Clerical, for the purpose of issuing the investigative finding to the allegation listed above. The LPA completed a safety inspection of the facility on 10/22/21 at 10:20 AM. During the course of the investigation, LPA Torres conducted confidential interviews with four out of six clients and six staff. On 10/20/21, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging the facility has rodents. It was alleged in August of 2021 a rodent could be heard eating on food in the cabinets and there were rodent droppings in the kitchen drawer that held utensils. It was further reported to the LPA; rodent droppings were also observed on the kitchen floor and a package of graham crackers had been bitten through. The rodent issue was not reported until the end of September 2021 because the staff wanted to tget more information and see the rodent with their own eyes. The report was made to a clerical staff, not management. *** Continued on next page ***

investigation_findings: On July 23, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted a complaint inspection at ARS-Berkeley and met with Kim Franck. While conducting the tele-inspection, LPA noted that C1's bed was missing the bedding. LPA Barragan asked S1 and S2 why C1's bedding was missing. S2 stated that C1's bedding was missing because C1 was sleeping on the couch in the living room. S2 elaborated that C1 was sleeping in the living room because he was scared and felt threatened by C2 due to C2 threatening to cause physical harm to C1 due to his sexuality. S2 elaborated that C2 had threatened C1 on more than one occasion, which resulted in C1 being to scared to sleep with C2. Staff stated that C1 had been sleeping in the living room. Interviews with other staff, clients and record review confirmed this information as well. "Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, Division & Chapter number), are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.") investigation_findings: On 11/03/2020, a follow-up complaint inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian for the ARS, Campus. A copy of this report was scanned to the Administrator with a request for signature and a scan back on this date.

The investigation to the above allegations was conducted by this LPA and it consisted of, but not limited to a review of records, including the clientâ€™s needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with 3 Staff members S1 on 9/10/2021, S3 on 9/16/21, S2 on 10/22/21, 2 of 4 clients C1 on 9/16/21, C2 on 9/28/21 (C3 was AWOL at the time of attempted interview and C4 declined to be interviewed) and CSW1 on 9/16/21 (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated March 29, 2022).
deficiency_1_description: 87072(b)(11) Personal Rights: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.  This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Per S1 - In order to ensure that this does not happen again all staff has been trained to utilize trauma-informed practices and to not remove any personal items from residents. And if and when we do, it will be due to the resident trying to harm themselves or others. Ensuring that residents have access to our mental health team, their therapist to help them understand their coping skills and other positive ways to express their behaviors will be key in the success of their treatment. To change or modify behavior our team will continue to use trauma-informed practices, work closely with all CFT members, and train staff on specific trauma informed interventions that will help that resident regulate more quickly.

investigation_findings: On July 12, 2023 at 9:15: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips conducted an unannounced visit to BOYS REPUBLIC SILVERLAKE RESIDENCE for the purpose of concluding the investigation and delivering findings on the above allegation. LPA met with STRTP Devon Hosey/Assistant Supervisor and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA Phillips interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Confidential interviews and records produced corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Staff interviews and video recording revealed Staff #2 allowed Child #1 to smoke vape pen in staffâ€™s vehicle. Client statements revealed that Staff #2 did not say anything or stop Child #1 from smoking vape pen. Based on information obtained and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC 9099 D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision.

deficiency_1_description:
87070 Children's Records (b) 	The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the childâ€™s record:
(14)A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following:
(A) 	The name of the medication.

(C) 	The quantity of medication and number of refills initially prescribed.
(D) 	When applicable, any additional refills prescribed.

(G)	Documentation of each refusal.

investigation_findings: On 7/15/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lisa Slusher travelled to Brighter Horizon Treatment Center, Elm, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program located in Clovis, CA and met with facility manager Precious Beard. Administrator Carolyn Ruffin was called by staff on site. The purpose of the inspection was to initiate an investigation into the above allegation. LPA conducted confidential interviews on this date, and also did a visual inspection of the facility vehicle. Upon visual inspection, LPA notes that there are two hazard lights which stay on continuously, the three seatbelts in the middle row of the vehicle are inoperable, handles are missing on the driver and passenger doors and the winshield is cracked. The vehicle was also observed to be dirty, with a large amount of trash observed. A full size tire is stored in the back of the vehicle, partially obstructing a rear view. The front license plate is not affixed to the vehicle. This allegation is substantiated and a deficiency is cited persuent to CCRR, Title 22, Division 6 General licensing regulations section 80074(c)

If facility personnel are to utilize personal vehicles, Administrator will ensure appropriate license, registration and insurance

investigation_findings: An unannounced inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 7/21/22 at 12:48 PM. investigation_findings: On September 16, 2022 at 1:38 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of the complaint investigation to the facility. The LPA met with Assistant Administrator, Laura Daniels. On June 27, 2022, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: the Assistant Administrator via telephone on September 13, 2022; and four clients Ref. #1, 2, 3 and 4 (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated September 13, 2022). The LPA was unable to interview two clients #5 and 6. The LPA reviewed the facility's complaint history and case management inspections. The LPA was able to corrobate at least three interviews that on at least one occasion, at least one client had to sit on the floor of a vehicle in order to be transported to and from the facility. The interviews revealed inconsistent information on which client was involved. At least one interview provided information on which vehicle, a Chevrolet Traverse, was used on one occasion. The interviews did not reveal information on which dates the incident or incidents occurred.

investigation_findings: On May 6, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, emailed the findings of the Complaint Investigation Report to Administrator, Pincess Wesley. On February 5, 2021, the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Office (RO) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: Administrator via telephone on April 27, 2021 and April 28, 2021; two Clients (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 and #2 dated May 6, 2021) via telephone on April 27, 2021. The LPA observed the following documents: Record of Client's/Resident's Safeguarded Cash Resources; Client/Resident Personal Property and Valuables and Clothing Inventory; Administrator's Certificate and Resume. The LPA conducted a tele-inspection on April 27, 2021. The investigation revealed that only one out of five Client/Resident Personal Property and Valuables and/or Clothing Inventory showed that clients received an adequate amount of clothing. Interviews with two clients revealed they received the allotted amount of clothing, but there were no records to corroborate the statements. There were confidential interviews that revealed that a staff purchased a client's clothing, because the facility did not.

investigation_findings: On 5/3/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Casa Esperanza Chino Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program for the purpose of a complaint investigation. LPA met with and interviewed Facility Manager James Brady regarding the above identified allegations. Investigation consisted of the following: LPA interviewed Facility manager, therapist, two (2) child care workers and three (3) children (see confidential names list LIC811, dated May 3, 2021). LPA toured the facility with child care worker and facility manager. LPA observed the following this is a single story, single family residence with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, office space, kitchen, front yard, backyard and attached garage. Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that the facility does not have adequate food supply and adequate lighting. Based on interviews conducted with facility manager, therapist, staff #1 (S1) overhead light in back office space is non-operational facility has floor lamp to provide lighting, however, LPA observed floor lamp to be missing a light bulb. Based on LPA inspection, LPA observed missing lightbulbs in bathroom #2 identified staff/ back up bathroom and bulb needing to be replaced in chandlier over bar as well as light bulb missing in office space floor lamp.
deficiency_1_description:
80088	Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies
This requirment was not met by: LPA observed missing light bulbs in bathroom #2, overhead light in office space was non operational and missing light bulb in chandilier
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Facility will fix or repair overhead light and replace on missing or burnt out light bulbs to provide adequate lighting within the facility. Facility will submit photos/ video of fixed lighting and light bulbs. Facility will provide by POC due date.

investigation_findings: On 10/22/2021 at 10:31 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with above staff. The purpose of the visit was to discuss and deliver findings for the above compliant allegations. While investigating the allegations, LPA Qualiema Green and LPA Yerkatyan conducted interviews with Staff, Clients, and County Social Workers (see Confidential Names LIC 811 dated October 22, 2021). Certain files were reviewed such as the facility personal roster, special incident reports, and training. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 did not adequately supervise C1 and allowed him to drive a car while C1 was impaired. It was revealed that S1 drove in the middle of the night to pick C1 up during off-duty hours. As S1 approached C1, C1 drove S1â€™s car and got a citation from law enforcement due to being impaired. Based on interviews, it was determined that S1 failed to ensure that C1 was properly supervised. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that S1 failed to meet Interim Licensing Standards. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were given.
deficiency_1_description: The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's or nonminor dependentâ€™s needs and services plan, or Transitional Independent Living Plan, as necessary to meet the child's or nonminor dependentâ€™s needs.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: S1 has resigned and is no longer employed with the facility as of 04/21/21. Training was provided to all staff regarding proper duty protocols. Proof of training was privided to LPA during visit.

investigation_findings: On October 28, 2020 at 2:45 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks conducted a follow-up complaint visit via telephone with Yakicewey Mitchell, Administrator. The purpose of the telephone visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation process, interviews were conducted with all related parties. Based on interviews, there was sufficient information to determine that there was an uncleared staff on the premises. An interview with the facility Administrator confirmed that Staff #1 had been working at facility without receiving a criminal record clearance. The Community Care Licensing Caregiver Background Check Bureau informed Staff #1 via letter that an exemption for an FBI Clearance was needed. Initially, The Caregiver Background Check Bureau allowed Staff #1 to be in the facility while the exemption was being processed. Program staff did not follow through in submitting the required documents to Caregiver Background Check, resulting in closure of the background exemption process. The closure letter was again provided to Administrator on July 3, 2020, stating that Staff #1 could not be present on the facility premises and must be immediately removed. Report continued on LIC9099-C

Criminal Record Clearance 80019(e)(1) All individuals subject to ..Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Deficiency was discussed with Administrator and Facility will submit written plan of correction regarding policy and procedure to ensure all staff will have a criminal record clearance before beginning work, no later than November 5, 2020.

investigation_findings: On May 28, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a follow-up compliant inspection to deliver findings from the Department's investigation. LPA Martin met with Anna Guerin Director of Clinical Services. The above-mentioned allegation was investigated by Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Philippe Ryan Miles. On December 27, 2020, CCLD received a complaint referral alleging Neglect / Lack of Supervision as Child #1 (C1) reportedly had access to hazardous items and C1 ingested hazardous items while in care (see Confidential Names form LIC811, dated 5/28/2021). Information obtained during the investigation including interviews and review of related medical records for C1 indicates in part, numerous hospitalization's for C1 due to ingesting foreign objects and being placed on involuntary psychiatric holds between August 2020 and February 2021. C1 was hospitalized on 12/14/2020, for â€œforeign body ingestionâ€ of glass. Records indicate C1 ingested two fistfuls of glass shards. On 08/31/2020, C1 was admitted to the hospital emergency room with complaint of swallowing glass and ingesting a metallic screw seen on x-ray. (Continued on next page - LIC9099-C)

investigation_findings: On 01/22/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Moua delivered the investigation finding for this complaint. LPA met with Heather Madison, Operations Manager, telephonically due to COVID precautions. LPA investigated the allegation that a lack of supervision resulted in an inappropriate sexual interaction between clients while in care. LPA conducted record reviews and interviews with four current residents, and three facility staff. LPA attempted to interview the â€œvictimâ€ on multiple occasions but was unsuccessful. During the course of the investigation, LPA discovered that the facility had immediately addressed the issues prior to the complaint allegations. On 05/12/2020, two overnight facility staff received performance warnings due to not providing the proper supervision as the incident(s) occurred during evening(s). On 05/13/2020, staff received training in supervision and room assignments were discussed between the treatment team. An additional late-night staff was also assigned to the house to provide additional supervision as the facility investigated the incident. The facility also sent a detailed Serious Incident Report to Community Care Licensing on 05/12/2020. Continued on 9099-C

On 01/26/2021, at approximately 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Moua communicated with this Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the findings of, and close, this complaint investigation. LPA contacted Heather Madison, Operations Manager. The Department has investigated allegations that Staff denied youth access to confidential telephone calls. The complaint investigation was opened on 08/26/2020 during which an interview with the facilityâ€™s Program Director was conducted. The following records were obtained: the facilityâ€™s Personnel Report (LIC500), a staff contact list, a current placement roster, the residentsâ€™ Needs and Services and Treatment Plans, and the credentials (license) of therapist T. Interviews were conducted with two direct-care staffers, a facility therapist, and three residents. Apart from one supporting documentation in the form of an email from one of the residentâ€™s Probation Officer, no court orders were produced by the facility that prescribed Charis staff to be present while residents are speaking on the phone, nor are there any explicit agreements with any of the other residentsâ€™ authorized representatives, guardians, and/or parents that allow staff to be supervising the youthsâ€™ phone calls. Continued on 9099-C
deficiency_1_description: Personal Rights: To make and receive confidential telephone calls, unless prohibited by court order.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Moving forward, the agency will ensure that restrictions made regarding phone calls will be documented in the resident files. Residents will have access to confidential phone calls where allowed, and staff will be trained in these procedures. The facility will provide the Department with proof of training by due date.

investigation_findings: This is an amended report that was issued on On August 5, 2022: On August 5, 2022 at 10:31 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegations. LPA met with quality assurance manager Amanda Bell. LPA Lorena Valenzuela conducted an inspection of the facility on October 25, 2022, at 11:31 am and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Three of three children (C1, C2, C3), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff #1 (S1) threw an object at C1 and S1 mishandled C1 with an inappropriate restraint. Confidential staff interviews reported that an incident occurred between S1 and C1 on October 11, 2021. Confidential staff interviews reported that S1 then threw a plastic bottle of soda at C1. Additional information then revealed that S1 then grabbed C1 by the arm, twisting it behind C1â€™s back and pushed up. Confidential staff interviews reported that the incident was investigated internally and reported to all appropriate parties. All of the interviews and proper documentation does corroborate the allegations. Continued on page 2

facility_name: CHILDREN'S HOME OF STOCKTON-ASPEN COMMUNITY HOME
investigation_findings: On 07/28/2021 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word delivered the investigation finding for this complaint. LPA met with Matt Nomura- Residential Director. During the investigation, interviews were conducted by LPA Word with employees, County Social Workers, residents FC2, FC3, and FC4, LPA Stephannie Verna conducted an interview with FC1. The LPA reviewed training logs for all current staff, Needs and Services plans for residents, Serious Incident Reports, and the facilityâ€™s policies and procedures. Residents FC2 and FC3 stated that they do not have any privacy in the home. Staff stated that the doors are removed when the residents refuse to keep them open. Staff stated that this is done to ensure residents do not self-harm, or smoke in the bedrooms. Residents FC2, FC3, and FC4 stated that this rule applies to all residents in the home regardless of self-harming behavior. On 7/28/2021 LPA Word observed FC1 ( see confidential name list dated 7/28/2021) door removed. Based on the LPAâ€™s observations; interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. (see continuation page 9099C)

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to let them know she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. LPA met with Facility Manager Betty Stanhope over FaceTime, a video conferencing application. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing pest control records, and conducting confidential interviews with the reporting party, facility manager, three staff, and eight clients on 11/24/2020, 2/2/2021, 2/3/2021, and 2/4/2021. LPA found through the pest control records in the last year that the facility was treated on 11/6/2019, 1/3/2020, 3/6/2020, 5/7/2020, 7/9/2020, 9/15/2020, and 11/5/2020. Based on interviews with staff and clients, LPA confirmed that there have sporadically and seasonally been issues with low amounts of cockroaches, ants, and spiders at the facility, but that they were taken care of by staff and by pest control treating the facility. Based on the interviews and pest control records, LPA has found the allegation that the facility has insects to be substantiated, or true. However, LPA also found that the facility handled these occasional pests appropriately. No citation issued.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne spoke with House Manager Delanie Whiteside on 12-14-20 at 11:21a.m. to deliver the findings of the above allegations. During this investigation a virtual inspection of the facility was conducted on 8-17-20. Copies of the staff schedule, staff roster and needs and services plan were obtained from the facility. Youth were interviewed on 10-29-20 and 11-24-20. Staff were interviewed on 11-30-20 (see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 8-17-20). It was alleged that facility staff engaged in inappropriate physical contact with resident in care. A resident had entered another resident's room and was told by a staff to leave the room. The staff and resident engaged in a verbal dispute which turned physical when the staff stated he grabbed the resident around the waist, pulled the resident down and they both fell onto the back of the couch. According to statements made, the staff had the resident in a choke hold. It was alleged that facility staff did not follow Community Care Licensing (CCL) reporting requirements. This LPA did not find any documentation of the above incident or any evidence that the incident was called in to the Officer of the Day phone line. Based on the information, the allegations are SUBSTANTIATED. (Continued on next page)

investigation_findings: On May 13, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan conducted a complaint inspection at Courage to Change and met with Joseph Lovett, Assistant Program. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff, client, and other parties; as well as reviewed documents that revealed that Courage to Change did not attempt to preserve placement prior to termination. In addition, information gathered verifies that Courage to Change did not follow appropriate procedures to try to mitigate permanent removal from the facility following temporary removal by law enforcement. Based on LPA's observations, interviews, and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations is being cited on this date for section 87068.4(c). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to Joseph Lovett.
deficiency_1_description: 87068.4(c) Removal and/or Transfer Procedures. This requirement is not met as evidence by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: A plan of correction will be submitted to the LPA by 5/16/2022.

investigation_findings: On November 1, 2024, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the complaint investigation. Prior to entering the facility LPA Gray conducted a health and safety risk assessment. During the investigation, LPA Gray interviewed all available parties and reviewed documentary evidence and video footage. Statements and review of documentary evidence and video footage were consistent that Staff 2 (S2) handled and spoke inappropriately to Child 1 (C1). In video footage, Staff 2 (S2) is observed handling Child 1 (C1) in a rough manner and confiscating C1 laptop/chrome book. Review of documentary evidence indicated that S2 resigned and provided a letter admitting to the allegations. S2 has been disassociated from all Dangerfield locations. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Article 6 Continuing Requirements 87072 (c)(16) - Personal Rights. S2 did not allow C1 to have access to their personal belongings and handled and spoke to C1 in an inappropriate manner.

investigation_findings: On 05/01/2025 at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility with the purpose of delivering complaint investigation findings to address late reporting to the authorized representative and the licensing. During this inspection, LPA met with Joellen Gutierrez, Administrator. During the initial visit on 03/24/25 LPA requested for the Administrator to provide initial e-mails that were sent to the authorized representatives and licensing for the incident in question to be forwarded to the LPA. LPA also interviewed the Administrator on 03/24/25. The Administrator admitted that the incident reports were not submitted within the CCLD timely guidelines due to on one instance staff being hospitalized and the Administrator not havng complete information about the incident, and in another instance staff did not follow the reporting requirements. On 03/25/25 LPA also interviewed the complainant. LPA reviewed initial and follow up e-mails from the Facility Administrator to licensing and the authorized representatives.

investigation_findings: The above-mentioned allegation was investigated by Community Care Licensing Special Investigator, Philippe Ryan Miles. On May 14, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin met with Janina Holt, Administrator to deliver and discuss findings. On March 31, 2020, Community Care Licensing received claims alleging a lack of supervision contributed to Client #1 (C1) engaging in sexual activities with an unidentified male while in the facility. The investigation consisting of interviews and review of corresponding records revealed the alleged unidentified male in question is a male minor, age 16 who C1 identified as her â€œboyfriendâ€. Based on gathered information from confidential interviews of witnesses, clients and staff members, there is corroborating evidence to support lack of supervision. Interviews revealed Staff #1 (S1) did not conduct any room checks while C1â€™s boyfriend was present in clientâ€™s room at the facility. S1 admitted she was unaware of an unidentified male being present in the facility since she failed to conduct routine room checks. S1 disclosed that she was under the assumption of knowing C1 â€œhaving the habit of staying in the room and not socializing with the residents in the living room.â€ S1 discovered the unidentified male was present at the facility when a neighbor witnessed the male jump the fence, after the (Continued on LIC9099-C)

80078 (a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision
The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee shall submit a written statement describing how the facility will ensure proper supervision for the safety to clients and ensure facility follows its policies and procedures to prevent such incidents from re-occurring.

investigation_findings: On May 6, 2021 at 1:15 pm, Out of State Certification Analyst, Ron Leslie conducted a a follow-up complaint investigation via telephone with Leroy Wise, Administrator, to discuss complaint allegations. During investigation of the allegation, facility staff did not intervene in youths physical altercation, the AGPA conducted interviews and reviewed serious incident reports, law enforcement reports and staff training records. Based on the information obtained, it is deteremined that staff did not intervene beyond verbal direction during the physical encounter of the two clients. Staff witnessed C1 obtain a plastic fork from the kitchen and returned back to the bedroom where C2 was located, having pushed past staff to do so. An altercation ensued between the clients resulting in the jabbing/stabbing of C2 and C3 by C1. Staff were out of position to appropriately de-escalate the incident. Two staff were on shift. Staff 2 was in the area where the incident occurred prior and during the altercation but did not prevent C1 from physically confronting C2 with the plastic fork. Staff 2 issued verbal commands while on the phone attempting to obtain direction from a supervisor.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and reports received.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Pro Act training requirement for S1 and S2 was met on 3/8/21. A training method has been propsed to include ProAct training at the corporate level vs the facility level. Follow-up required. Staff schedules will be reviewed in an attempt to maintain a balance with staff on shift based, on experience.

investigation_findings: On August 11, 2022 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at DIMONDALE ADOLESCENT CARE FACILITY #3 to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. LPA Martin met with Ashley Ross, Administrator to discuss the investigative outcome. The investigation was conducted by Investigator Dennis Douglas of the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau. On February 8, 2022, CCLD received complaint allegations concerning neglect/lack of supervision resulting in the injury of a facility Client as Client #1 (C1) (see LIC811, dated 8/11/2022) was reportedly assaulted by several non-resident juveniles while in care. On February 11, 2022, LPA Regina Martin, conducted the initial complaint inspection and obtained related documentation. Investigator Douglas completed the investigation which included, confidential interviews with related clients/residents, staff members, review of documented witness statements, review of related client file and incident reports, and review of the Hawthorne Police Department Incident Report. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

investigation_findings: On September 2, 2022 at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to Dimondale Adolescent Care Facility #3 for the purpose of delivering findings on the above allegations. investigation_findings: On October 25, 2023 at 11:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. LPA Martin met with Shaundrea Menefield, Facility Administrator, to discuss the investigative outcome. On March 23, 2023, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received a complaint alleging that Staff #1 (S1) [See LIC811, dated 10/25/2023] provided youth residents with alcohol and marijuana and facility staff failed to supervise residents contributing to residents' fighting and consuming alcohol/marijuana. The investigation was referred to and conducted by Investigator Heidy Bendana of the CCLD Investigations Branch. On March 24, 2023, LPA Regina Martin conducted the initial complaint inspection, informed licensee receipt of the allegation, subsequent investigation and obtained requested related records. Further investigation including review of facility file history, review of related incident reports, review of staff file history, as well as confidential interviews with residents, staff members and review of related documentary proof, revealed enough evidence to support lack of supervision and conduct inimical. (Continued on page LIC 9099)

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward arrived at the facility at 2:00 PM to investigate the above allegations. LPA met with administratrator Shaundrea Menefield who assisted with the inspection. LPA noted that there was no air conditioning in the bedrooms. However, there were workmen there who were installing air conditioning in the living room area and the bedrooms. LPA Jones-Steward did see mold growing along the ceiling of the hallway bathroom. LPA also noticed a small strip of peeling paint on the wall of bedroom #2. LPA interviewed clients and staff who confirmed that there is no air conditioning in the bedrooms and that it gets very warm. The above allegations were substantiated and the facility was cited under Title 22 Sections 80088(a) and 80087(a).

investigation_findings: On May 7, 2025 at 12:30 PM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong conducted an unannounced visit to DIMONDALE ADOLESCENT CARE FACILITY #3 to conclude the investigation of the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA met with Leroy Wise the Administrator, at the facility, and together, they discussed the investigation details. During the investigation, all relevant parties were accounted for. It was initially reported that the staff not setting limits between staff and minor. The facility conducted an internal investigation, resulting in the suspension of S3 pending the investigation's conclusion. Interviews and documentary evidence indicated that S3 acknowledged a resident had visited a family member; however, this visit did not occur at S3's personal residence. Employees are prohibited from having contact or any type of relationship with residents outside of the workplace. (See LIC 9099C)

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed the complainant, two staff members and C2. C1 could not be reached. LPA also reviewed intake agreements and initial Needs & Services Plans for C1 & C2. Based on the investigation, it was determined that in the past Dimondale 6 did not provide adequate transportation to clients' school of origin but rather provided Metro Transit passes so that clients could reach their schools using public transportation. This does not satisfy Title 22 regulations regarding transportation of clients. The licensee was cited under Title 22 Section 87074(c) and 87074(f)
deficiency_1_description:
Transportation
Unless other arrangements are specified in the needs and services plan  for a child or nonminor dependent, a licensee shall ensure transportation is provided to school and other necessary destinations.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensorrective action plan that defines how it will handle transportation arrangements for clients.
deficiency_2_description:
Transportation
The licensee may satisfy its obligation to provide transportation as required by this section if the licensee has entered into a written agreement with a third party for the regular provision of transportation.
deficiency_2_plan_of_correction: The licensorrective action plan that defines how it will handle transportation arrangements for clients.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the allegation that a staff member has an inapproproate reationship with a minor. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed C1, S1, S2, the LA County social worker for C1 and school personnel. Based on the information that LPA was able to obtain, S1 did have an inappropriate relationship with C1 by mainitaining contact with him while he was on unauthorized absence from the facility and posing as his mother to try to enroll him in school. The management of Dimondale conducted an internal investigation into the matter, determined that S1 violated protocol and terminated her employment on May 2, 2025. Based on the available evidence the allegation that staff had an inppropriate relationship with a client is substantiated. Substantiated means that there is a preponderence of evidence that the allegation is true. The licensee was cited under HSC 1569.58 (a)(2)
deficiency_1_description:
Conduct Inimnical
The department may prohibit any person from being a licensee,  from employing, or continuing the employment of any person who is found guilty of conduct which is inimnical to clients in care or the people of the State of California
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a corrective action plan to detail how to prevent furure occurances of this nature,

investigation_findings: On 7/20/2021, at 11:27 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced inspection to the above facility, for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and to deliver the findings. LPA spoke with the facility manager Darryl Theus, and together discussed the investigation details. Staff and clients confirmed that an unknown person entered the facility through the window and assaulted C1 in front of C2 and C3. C1 stated that an unknown person hit him and the only thing he could do was cover his head. During that time of the incident, clients and staff confirmed that S2 was doing paperwork in the office and arrived in the room after the unknown person had already left the facility. S1 was concerned that S2 did not hear anything and did not react earlier when the unknown individual entered the facility through the window. During LPA Hernandez's visit to the facility on 7/13/2021, S1 demonstrated to LPA how clearly the noise can be heard from the office. Based on LPA interviews and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A deficiency was cited to the facility for Neglect Lack of supervision. Exit interview was conducted and Plans of Corrections were reviewed and developed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and left with the facility manager whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.
