investigation_findings: On 3/26/2021 and 12:08 pm Out of State Group Home Analyst Sarah Waklee conducted an announced telephone call to Dimondale Adolescent #9 Academy Administrator Janina Holt, in regards to a complaint the department received on 2/26/2021. In the course of the investigation Analyst Waklee interviewed the Administrator, reporting party, and three youth. All three youth admitted to smoking a cigarette in front of the facility. Based on this information there is a preponderance of evidence that youth were smoking on facility grounds. Therefore the above allegation is substantiated. The facility cited for violation of the Intern Licensing Standards, Version 3.1, Section 87087 Building and Grounds 87087(c) The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility. A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.
deficiency_1_description: 87087 Building and Grounds(c) The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Plan of correction was discussed. Facility will ensure supervision is being provided while youth are taking breaks outside in the front and back of the facility. Facility advised to create a sign in sheet, noting the time youth went outside, returned inside and who provided supervision.

investigation_findings: On October 1, 2021, at 11:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced visit to for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and to deliver the findings. LPA met with Facility Administrator Janina Holt who granted access to Dimondale #2 where she was and together discussed the investigation details.During the investigative process, LPA interviewed all relevant parties to this complaint. FA confirmed that C1's psychotropic medication was not administered by staff. The reason FA found out that C1 was not taking psychotropic medication was during a CFT meeting because SW informed FA. FA said there was a lack of communication from the staff and after that incident their policies have changed. C1 confirmed that not taking the medication because the facility did not provide it for a couple of weeks. C1 noticed by not taking the medication C1's behaviors increased by Awoling more often and being upset all the time. In addition, SW was concerned the facility did not provide the medication to C1 and they were not aware of it. Based on LPA interviews and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A deficiency was cited to the facility for Health-Related Services. (See 9099-D).
deficiency_1_description:
80075 (b)(5)(B) Health Related Services.  Medications shall be given according to physician's directions.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee shall submit to LPA Hernandez by 10/4//2021 a plan of correction, including but not limited to staff training, in order to ensure that medication are administer as prescribed by a physician .

investigation_findings: On 1/31/25 at 11:08 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at Dream Home Care V and met with Admin Kevin Benett for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegations. LPA interviewed involved staff and clients. Interview evidence and record review revealed that the facility is not implementing proper written complaint procedures for minors in care. Interviews reveal that clients donâ€™t know or remember the complaint procedures and donâ€™t feel they will remain anonymous. Additionally, interviews reveal that complaints are discussed publicly which also contributes to the lack of anonymity for the complainant. The actions to address and correct received complaints should allow the complainant to remain anonymous during the process.

The licensee shall develop, maintain and implement accessible written complaint procedures by which children,... are permitted to file complaints, without fear of retaliation, with the facility administrator regarding facility staff or operations. This requirement is not met as

investigation_findings: On October 11, 2023 @ 3:35PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made a follow up visit to DREAM HOME CARE INC.I for the purpose of delivering findings on the allegation listed above. During the investigation LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidences. Statements were consistent and documentary evidences indicated that staff was sleep while on duty. Based on the documentary evidence obtained by LPA a staff write up for sleeping on duty. The documentary evidence did produce corroborating evidence to support the allegation: Staff were sleeping on the job. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and representatives. Staff, clients and representatives interviewed stated staff often use wrong, or derogatory names to address clients. Many times intentional and sometimes by mistake. Staff admitted that the facility is unable to provide the proper care or training, and other staff stated that staff should be trained in gender affirming/sensitivity training. investigation_findings: On 12/11/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings from a complaint investigation. LPA met with met with Mental Health Residential Specialist (MHRS), Som Souksumphan and spoke with Administrator, Derrick Kennedy over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. The complaint alleged that staff did not prevent a physical altercation between children resulting in a child's injuries. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, the following was found. On 10/5/24 a physical altercation occurred at the Vista facility which resulted in two clientsâ€™ injuries. Before the physical altercation, two Vista residents appeared at the Horizons facility unannounced. Staff at Horizons was aware of the conflicts between the residents and did not allow the Vista residents to enter, however, staff did not communicate the Vista residentâ€™s presence at Horizon facility to Vista staff. There had been no internal communication between staff on shift at either facility on 10/5/24 regarding the residentâ€™s whereabouts, therefore, staff did not prevent the physical altercation that occurred. (Report continued on LIC9099-C)

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Amy Green, Supervisor. LPA Brown and LPA Yesenia Vallejo conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Brown initiated the investigation with the facility on 04/08/2025 and three staff members were interviewed. A Health and Safety Inspection was conducted. LPA Vallejo interviewed two county social workers and LPA Brown conducted a total of nine confidential interviews. LPA reviewed records including: incident reports, staff training records, Needs and Services plans, daily progress notes, and Child and Family Team meeting notes. The complaint allegation indicates that staff inappropriately restrained a minor in care. While there was some discrepancy as to how the client was restrained, the staff member in question admitted to having the client by the arm to prevent them from leaving, and witnesses were consistent that the staff member had grabbed and held the client by the arm. Restricting the client from leaving in this manner is not an approved restraint as part of the facilityâ€™s emergency intervention plan.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Amy Green, Facility Supervisor and Eric Perry Administrator joined by phone. LPA conducted the complaint investigation. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed seven other staff members, one probation officer, one county social worker, and five other confidential interviewees. It was alleged that staff speak inappropriately to clients by swearing at and calling them names. Interviews

investigation_findings: On 6-28-24 9:27AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at Filbert House, and met with Ken Porter, Administrator, who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. The complaint alleged that uncleared staff allowed to work at the facility and staff falsified youthsâ€™ rehabilitation documents. On 6-10-24 10:15AM, LPA made an unannounced inspection at Filbert House. LPA was greeted by S1, LPA obtained S1â€™s California Identification Card and confirmed S1â€™s identity. S1 stated that they have been employed at Filbert House for over one year. LPA checked S1â€™s status on Guardian and found it â€œIn Processâ€. S1 does not have fingerprint clearance. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff that stated S4 had copied/pasted and erased youthsâ€™ rehabilitation notes, S4 immediately terminated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03 Criminal Record Clearance 80019(e)(1), with a civil penalty, and Interim Licensing Standards, Article 06, Needs and Service Plans 87068.2(a). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was given to Ken Porter.

Based on the documentary evidence, interviews, and statements obtained during the investigation process, LPA was able to corroborate the allegations, Staff member handled minor in a rough manner and Staff member used inappropriate language toward minor. Although Client #1 (C1) threw the remote control at the television because staff threw away C1â€™s cereal, confidential interviews, consistent statements, and documentary evidence revealed S1 grabbed C1 by their neck and pushed C1 to the floor. S1 used inappropriate language toward C1 while holding C1 on the back of the neck on the floor.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an unannounced complaint investigation at the facility and met with Deputy Director Timothy Dimick, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings on the above allegation. During the course of the investigation LPA Bertoli interviewed 2 staff and the complainant, and reviewed records. The records and the interviews indicated that although the Needs and Services Plan was prepared for client C1 (see LIC 811 form dated 02/03/22), it was not sent for signature of the Authorized Representative until it was requested by them in August 2021. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility did not properly complete the Needs and Services Plan. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Title 22 deficiencies were cited and Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with Deputy Director Dimick.

During investigation of the allegations; youth engaged in physical altercation while in care resulting in injury, the AGPA conducted interviews, reviewed serious incident reports, medical reports and law enforcement contact reports. Although the staff directly involved were not available to be interviewed, the documents outlining the incident along with interviews conducted confirmed that staff did not de-escalate the event appropriately. X2 was noted to have been the agressor and was alotted multiple opportunities to physically engage X1. Staff utilized their person to block X2 from X1 after assaults from X2 to X1 had occurred. The use of physical intervention as a result of failed attempts to re-direct or verbally de-escalate was not initiated.

investigation_findings: On May 3, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin met with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs via Microsoft Teams Meeting to deliver and discuss findings from the investigation concerning the allegation as mentioned above. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing Special Investigator, Edward Hector. On December 14, 2020, Community Care Licensing received claims alleging a lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate sexual contact between clients as it was reported that Client #2 (C2) was a victim of sexual assault by Client #1 (C1) while in the facility. The investigation included a review of client files, review of the Los Angeles Sheriffs Department report and confidential interviews conducted with clients and staff members. The investigation revealed from gathered information, C1 and C2 engaged in oral sex. Reportedly, C1 coerced C2 to have oral sex with him. (Continued on next page LIC9099-C)

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess, LPA Chad Cabigon, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez met with Director Annette Jumper and CEO David Baker during an informal office meeting to deliver the findings of this complaint. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing Medication Administration Records (MAR), Faxes, Central Stored Medication and Destruction Record (CSMDR), Prescriptions, Incident Reports, Write-Ups and Refresher Training documents, and by conducting confidential interviews with the Reporting Party and three staff, including Administration staff, on 3/18/2021, 6/8/2021, and 6/9/2021. Based on interviews and review of the CSMDR, MARs, Fax, Prescriptions and interviews with staff, LPA found that the client who it was alleged to have missed medication, even though it was still recorded on the client's MAR that he was taking the medication, did miss one dose of medication, however it was not the fault of the facility.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess, LPA Chad Cabigon, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez met with Director Annette Jumper and CEO David Baker during an informal office meeting to deliver the findings of this complaint. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing staff communication notes, email correspondence, pest control records, and by conducting confidential interviews with the Reporting Party and nine staff, including Administration staff, on 2/16/2021, 6/8/2021, and 6/9/2021. LPA found based on interviews that the facility did have an issue with gnats entering the facility in the pantry. Around mid-January the facility had a plumbing company come out to assess what the problem was with a pipe due to a strong odor and the gnats, and during so, many more gnats entered the facility in the pantry through the crawlspace. When this happened, the facility called a pest

LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing extermination records and emails, incident reports, and by conducting confidential interviews with nine clients, seven staff, and the reporting party on 9/28/2020, 10/12/2020, 11/5/2020, 12/9/2020, 12/10/2020, 12/14/2020, and 12/16/2020. Two clients declined to be interviewed. Based on the interviews, LPA confirmed that the facility did previously have a flea infestation in the campus's fields of grass, and cottage. This infestation did affect both clients and staff, with them getting bitten. Clients were provided with bug spray and itch cream when needed to keep the clients protected. The facility did address the issue multiple times with exterminators until the problem was erradicated. LPA found the allegation that the facility is infested with insects to be substantiated, or true. However, based on evidence the facility handled the infestation appropriately. No citation will be issued.

investigation_findings: On September 4, 2021 at 12:45PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted an unannounced complaint inspection at the above facility for the purpose of delivering findings. AGPA met with Stephanie Renteria-Perez, Facility Manager. During the course of the investigation, AGPA Woodard conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients and other relative parties. Staff state they will use their own money for facility related projects, gasoline, oil changes, food, etc. and it takes about 1-3 weeks to get reimbursed. 95% of the food at the facility is purchased from the food bank. When interviewing the CEO he stated there were no outstanding reimbursements, but in other interviews reimbursements are up to $70,000 pending. CEO signs off on his and the Executive Director's reimbursements, however Balance Financial Services states that "Executive team members do not approve their own expenses. Reimbursements are approved by another manager." Based on interviews and documentation received through the course of this investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A deficiency was cited to the facility for Finances (See 9099-D). Exit interview was conducted, signature from Facility Representative was received, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: On January 14, 2022, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted an announced complaint inspection at the above facility for the purpose of delivering findings. Upon arrival, AGPA met with Taylor Abernethy, Program Manager. On January 9, 2022, AGPA Woodard conducted the initial 10-day complaint inspection. At time of inspection, AGPA conducted a tour with S1 of the cottage, dining hall, and Stone House Kitchen. During the tour of the cottage, AGPA observed food not properly sealed and old fruit. In the dining hall, observed prepared food in a pot with a metal spoon dated 12/31/2021 and also a bowl of prepared Caesar Salad with no date, and Orange Juice marked â€œEnjoy Before 12/16/21â€. In the Stone House Kitchen, there was romaine lettuce that was withering and browning marked packaged 12/17/21, a container of molded cheese, another gallon of Orange Juice marked â€œEnjoy Before 12/16/21â€, a packaged of hamburger meat with a sticker Reduced to $5 marked â€œUse by 01/08/2022â€, a box of snacks in damaged boxes and/or broken seals, and meat in the freezer with reduced stickers marked â€œuse or freeze by Sept 30, 2021, and a box marked Ahi Tuna with a date 7/25 written on it. Based on observations, AGPA Woodard has determined the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegations are found to be substantiated. investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients as well as reviewed documents which revealed that staff failed to protect youth from being harmed by other residents. On 09/16/2020, staff were not supervising clients when a fight broke out between two clients in the home. The tension between the clients continued and escalated to another fight outside the home involving four clients which again, staff did not prevent or intervene. The documentation obtained does not demonstrate the efforts made by the facility staff to de-escalate the first fight in the home; prevent clients from leaving the home; or what was done to prevent any further incidents between the clients. Based on the information obtained, staff failed to protect youth. Based on LPA's observations, interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients as well as obtained relevant documents. Confidential interviews and documents reveal that facility was not aware of minorâ€™s whereabouts and staff did not check ID when minor was picked up for a day pass. On July 11, 2022, minor was authorized a day pass with bio family. When the minor was picked up, staff did not ensure minor was picked up by only authorized individuals according to the minorâ€™s Needs and Services Plan as they did not verify identification. Facility staff assumed minor was picked up by bio family and would spend the time with bio family. However, interviews reveal minor was not picked up by bio family and did not spend the time with bio family. As a result, facility staff did not know minorâ€™s true whereabouts and allowed minor to leave the facility with an unauthorized individual. Based on the information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Natalia Yado. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and obtained relevant documents which revealed that facility staff mismanaged youth's medications while in care. Confidential interviews confirm that staff gave youth the medication she arrived with and was provided by the county social worker. Youth was placed in the home on August 17, 2022 and was discharged from the home on September 13, 2022. The facility received a copy the JV223 that was granted on July 19, 2022 after youth was placed in the home. A copy of the JV223 was obtained from the facility but only consisted of two pages with no list of the medication prescribed. Medication records are consistent with the medication the youth received during her stay at the home. However, the youthâ€™s Needs and Service Plan for August lists a different set of medication which does not match the medication records. According to the JV220 an JV220 attachment provided by the CSW, the medication listed on the NSP was the correct medication that was prescribed and should have been given to the youth. The facility staff did not confirm with the county social worker the medication the youth was to take according to the JV223 that was granted on July 2022. Based on LPA's observations and interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

investigation_findings: On 8/5/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit at the facility in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator George Jordan and Facility Manager Nathan Austin and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review: It was found that the facility scheduled a psychiatric appointment at which a resident's psychotropic medication was paused. The authorized representative was not present at the appointment nor consulted during the appointment but had agreed, along with the resident, to have the resident be seen by a physician to lower this medication. The current JV-216 Order Delegating Judicial Authority Over Psychotropic Medication delegated the authorized representative authority to approve or deny psychotropic medication, and a recent court order mandated that medical decisions be approved by the authorized representative. SEE NEXT PAGE

investigation_findings: On 8/5/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit at the facility in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator George Jordan and Facility Manager Nathan Austin and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review: It was found that pharmacy records reflected a 30-day supply was provided at each refill of two inhaler medications, but more than 30 days surpassed between refills. The medication administration records had multiple discrepancies, including duplicate documentation of administration of one inhaler medication, incorrect fill dates, and incorrect identification of medications resulting in documentation reflecting a potential over-administration and under-administration of two separate inhaler medications. Staff were unable to explain these discrepancies. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. SEE NEXT PAGE

investigation_findings: On Monday December 13, 2021 @ 3:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a Tele-Inspection to deliver investigation findings for allegation listed above. LPA Landry conducted the entrance interview with Manager listed above. This investigation initially began on 9/15/2020 and since then more information has been received. Based on information received Child #1 was transported to the city of Riverside California on or around 09/04/2020 in the company's van by staff #1. The temperature reached 103 degrees on that date. Based on interviews it was reported by client(s) and staff the air conditioner inside the company's van was not working efficiently and thereby caused child #1 to have nausea, a headache and panic attack. Although LPA Landry was unable to determine the exact date the air conditioner ceased working it was reported to have been broken before the trip to Court in Riverside, Ca on 9/04/20. Based on further information received it was reported the facility's van was lacking Freon. However, maintenance information was never received verifying exactly why vehicle was not in safe operating condition. Based on LPAâ€™s observation and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED ------->

investigation_findings: On 4/7/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an initial complaint inspection. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. CEO Carizma Chapman entered the facility at around 1:45PM. During the visit, LPA conducted a tour of the facility and grounds with Administrator and obtained photos. LPA observed the kitchen trash can to be placed on top of the lid, meaning it was being used without a lid. LPA observed expired food in the upstairs cabinets and refrigerator and in the downstairs emergency food supply, including rotten bell pepper, expired cans of soup and sausages, and old cereal in open bags with no boxes. The emergency food supply log was last updated on 2/19/21 and includes more food than was available in the cabinets, and much of the food was expired. Administrator confirmed more food would be purchased but also confirmed that there was a lot less food last week.
met_with: Administrator Sonam Prasad; CEO Carizma Chapman

investigation_findings: On 03/27/24 at 1:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of delivering investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad to inform on the purpose of the visit. Facility did not report incident by the next business day or provide a written report within the seven-day period. Based on LPAâ€™s observations, interviews, and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is SUBSTANTIATED. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80061 Reporting Requirements. Reference LIC9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Sonam Prasad, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: On Friday 9/24/21 at 3PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with resident and staff as well as reviewed video footage of the incident. Video footage posted on social media site Instagram shows at least three residents were upstairs during the incidents where two residents were antagonizing resident R1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names). The two residents are believed to be R2 and R3, and Administrator confirmed the identity of R3. The residents are shown filming themselves call R1 out of R1's room and splash R1 with a cup of water as R1 exited the room, hitting R1 and the door as R1 closed the door. Footage also shows residents enter R1's room while R1 was asleep and hit R1.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Only one of the involved residents is still in care.  Per Administrator, the facility has been planning on increasing staff presence at site.  Licensee agrees to formalize this plan and to submit an updated staffing plan that demonstrates the increased staff to child ratio along with an LIC 500.

investigation_findings: On 4/20/22 at 2:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and screening call. This investigation was conducted by the Investigations Branch. During the investigation of the above allegation(s), confidential interviews were conducted with residents, staff, and authorized representative, and police report was reviewed. Based on interviews and record review, staff S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 4/20/22) performed a single-person prone restraint on resident R1 while second staff S2 had gone outside to call law enforcement for support, and to lower R1 to the floor, S1 â€œswept [R1â€™s] legs out from under him.â€ R1 placed hands behind back, and S1 held hands down to hold R1 down in restraint, as witnessed by second staff. Additionally, prior to the restraint, while staff attempted to de-escalate, R1 was cornered in R1â€™s room by S1, per S1â€™s telling of events, when youth was close enough to staff to hit staff and also close enough to the wall to cause a hole when bringing arm back to then hit staff. S1 was not able to explain why staff and resident were in this position.

investigation_findings: On 7/24/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an initial visit to the facility regarding an investigation into the complaint allegations listed above. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interview, record review, and observation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. It was found that a plan was made with a 13-year-old resident's authorized representative to transport the resident to the airport and meet with the authorized representative, who would be accompanying the resident on the flight. Staff provided transportation to the airport but not to the authorized representative as agreed and therefore did not follow the transportation plan. Staff left the resident unattended at the wrong terminal without a phone, ID, or plane ticket and did not meet with the authorized representative nor inform them of arrival to the airport. SEE LIC 9099-C.

investigation_findings: On Thusday 8/5/21, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver complaint investigation findings for the above allegation. LPA met with Asst. Director La Tanya Harper and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on record review, police investigation, and confidential interviews, the allegation is regarding an incident in which a resident caused damage to a staff's vehicle and another staff interacted inappropriately with youth. During the incident, staff S1 (see LIC 811 Confidential Names) confirmed to police that S1 stated to youth R1 when R1 pulled out a knife, "You're bringing a knife to a gun fight," though S1 later denied this in interview with LPA. Police found an illegally concealed firearm during a search of S1's vehicle. S1 stated to police that S1 did not know at the time that S1's coworker (S2) had put S2's gun in S1's vehicle after extensive damage was caused to S2's vehicle earlier that day. S1 denied brandishing the weapon. Based on involved resident interview, S1 made a statement about we're not fighting but we're shooting.

investigation_findings: On Thursday 11/05/20 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver findings of a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Assistant Director La Tanya Harper and Interim Administrator Tracy McWoodson. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was scheduled as a tele-visit. During the investigation, LPA Hawkins conducted confidential interviews with staff, social worker, and probation officer. Based on interviews and record review, following an incidence of aggression that resulted in an altercation involving each youth in placement at the time, the police were called for assistance and resident R1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) was 5150â€™d and taken to the hospital. A probation officer who oversaw this case reported that Probation would not pick up R1 because R1 did violate probation. R1â€™s social worker reported that the facility told the social worker that they refused to pick up R1 and bring back into care, because they felt that R1 was not fit for congregate care. The social worker suggested they do a 14-day notice, and the facility refused.
met_with: Assistant Director La Tanya Harper and Interim Administrator Tracy McWoodson

investigation_findings: On Thursday 11/18/21 at 3PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Tracy McWoodson and ifnormed of the purpose of the visit. During investigation, LPA reviewed resident records and conducted confidential interviews with resident, staff, and social worker. Based on the report, the above allegation pertains to resident R1 (see LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 11/18/21) not being picked up from school. Based on interviews, the reason given by the facility for not picking up R1 from school was that it was part of R1's transitional plan to find transportation home. However, this was not reflected in R1's needs and services plan. The needs and services plan dated 9/24/21 includes the following: "Transition Plan: [R1]'s current plan is to graduate high school and move back with her grandmother or transition to a county connected independent living program. The staff and counselors at Lighthouse Mentoring Center are supporting [R1]'s connection with her grandmother and guiding and educating her on the resources available through the Independent Living Program."

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit an updated needs and services / transitional plan for R1 with the current transportation plan that includes the available bus routes that R1 may take. investigation_findings: On 4/20/22 at 11:45AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. During the investigation of the above allegation(s), LPA conducted confidential interviews with residents and facility staff. Based on interviews, staff and administrator confirmed the following occurred: Staff S1â€™s (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) daughter (P1) came inside the facility and immediately went upstairs and verbally assaulted resident R1 in an upstairs bedroom. Staff S2 attempted to de-escalate the situation and calm P1, and P1 left the facility. R1 followed P1 outside despite S2â€™s attempts to prevent this. When outside, P1 and P1â€™s son physically assaulted R1 by hitting R1 and throwing a water jug (thrown by P1â€™s son) at R1. Prior to the incident, in the morning, S1 was at the facility past S1â€™s shift and had taken a call with P1 to discuss a non-urgent, personal matter. During the call, R1 had spoken disrespectfully to S1.

investigation_findings: On 4/20/22 at 11:02AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. investigation_findings: On 1/9/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings for the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Tracy McWoodson and Clinical Director Phyllis Ritter and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review, a staff member who worked the overnight shift, a shift that is not typically tasked with morning school transportation, transported a resident to school due to the need to leave early to transport to an out of county school. During one transport, the staff member was falling asleep at stop lights. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87074 Transportation. See attached LIC 9099-D. The staff member was immediately taken off of morning transportation, and a plan was developed to ensure the resident was transported to school, with an agreement between the care team and school to have morning shift staff transport the resident, resulting in the resident arriving a bit later than usual.
met_with: Administrator Tracy McWoodson, Clinical Director Phyllis Ritter

investigation_findings: On Novermber 10, 2020 at 9:24am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jose Gonzalez contacted Administrator (AD), Jerome Jordan of Maywright Group Home to discuss the investigative findings for the allegations noted above due to COVID-19 tele-inspection was conducted. LPA inspected the facility at 9:55 am on November 26, 2019 and reviewed staffâ€™s files and five out of five residentsâ€™ records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with five out of five residents, Administrator (AD), Facility Manager (FM), and County Social Worker (CSW). The Department received a complaint on November 20, 2019, that alleged facility staff withheld resident 1 (R1) allowance. Confidential witness statements indicate that the facility staff withheld R1â€™s allowance. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff held R1 allowance because R1 has a history of substance abuse and was using their allowance money to purchase illicit drugs. Confidential witness statements revealed that R1 was not given R1 allowance as a deterrent from purchasing drugs and alcohol. **CONT on 9099C**

investigation_findings: On March 19, 2024, at 10:13 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Maywright Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed Clients (C1 and C2), STRTP staff (S1 and S2), and the County Social Worker (CSW). LPA attempted to interview C3, C4, and C5 but was unsuccessful because C3s whereabouts were unknown, and clients (C4 and C5) declined to be interviewed. On 01/23/2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff (S2) mismanaged a child's (C1) medication. It was alleged there was a medication error, and S2 accidentally administered C3â€™s medication to C1. The incident report provided to the Department on 01/19/2024 confirmed that C1 was mistakenly given the wrong medication.The incident report states that S2 immediately reported the mistake to S1, and C1 received medical attention.
deficiency_1_description:
Health Related Services (a) In addition to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80075, the following shall apply
(c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee will provide staff retraining on medication management and include ways to avoid this deficiency in the future.

investigation_findings: On October 28, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Patricia White, Program Director. The purpose of the visit was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA Perez conducted interviews with three staff and one client on October 07, 2021, LPA conducted interviews with two clients on October 18, 2021, LPA conducted an interview with one staff via telephone on October 19, 2021 and LPA conducted an interview with one staff via telephone on October 21,2021 (see Confidential Names LIC 811 dated October 31, 2021). LPA analyzed pertinent documents such as client's case notes, special incidents reports and need and services plan. It was alleged that a STRTP minor had an inappropriate interaction with another minor while in care.

On December 28, 2021 at 1:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegation above. The complaint was investigated by Community Care Licensing, Investigations Branch, Investigator Olivia Spindola. LPA Rarela met with the facility representative named above and discussed the findings. During the course of the investigation, Investigator Spindola interviewed a facility cottage manager on 10/12/21, facility director on 10/12/21, and facility clients on 12/2/21 and 12/7/21; Investigator Spindola went to the last known address of a facility client on 12/2/21 and 12/7/21 and attempted to telephone the client's last known contact information on 12/6/21 and 12/7/21 but was unable to make contact. Investigator Spindola also reviewed documents on 9/9/21 including placing agency records, incident reports, and Needs and Services Plans of clients; Investigator Spindola requested police reports which were not received at the conclusion of this investigation. (CONTINUED)

investigation_findings: On 02/18/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a follow up complaint inspection for the Merced Ranch STRTP and met with Program Director Brandi Boehme. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via teleinspection. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the findings for the above allegations. Interviews were conducted of staff and witnesses. Minor (#1) refused to be interviewed, however interviews conducted by other parties were reviewed. Interviews conducted state staff member (#1) locked one of the doors to the facility when the minor (#2) was outside, used another youth (#3) to intimidate the minor (#2), hit the minor (#2) while outside, used curse words towards the minor (#2) when he was attempting to damage staff's (#1) vehicle, pulled the minor's (#2) and conducted an inappropriate restraint on the minor (#2). Based on the above, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations and, therefore, the complaint is substantiated. Deficiencies on the attached page. A copy of this report is scanned to the Program Director on this date with a request for signature and scan back on this date.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Charles Smith. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation regarding the staff not preventing minors from smoking illegal substances while in care. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews with clients, staff, and school personnel. The information obtained during the interviews, indicated that the minors were permitted to smoke with a vape pen. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Based on the LPAâ€™s observations, interviews, and the records review conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegation is found to be substantiated. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the STRTP.
deficiency_1_description: 87074(b)-Transportation-The licensee and staff are prohibited from smoking...or permitting any person from smoking a tobacco product in a motor vehicle that is regularly used to transport children...This requirement
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: STRTP staff will continue to check clients prior to entering the vehicle. STRTP will install a video camera in the van to monitor actions of passengers.  STRTP will retrain on transportation and safety, to include no smoking

investigation_findings: On August 3, 2003 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) was met by facility representative Will Hayes. The purpose for this inspection is to seek additional information and conduct interviews with the minors in care. LPA previously obtained copies of Needs and Services Plans, Admission agreements and client roster for the facility on August 2, 2023. LPA conducted interviews with three of the four minors in care. 1 minor was attending summer school during this inspection. Based on confidential interviews with staff and minors along with record review, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for a violation of Interim Licensing Standards STRTP, Title 22, Division 6, Section 87061(b-f) Reporting Requirements An exit interview was conducted with Will Hayes and a copy of this report, and appeal rights were provided.

Confidential interviews reported that on October 29, 2021 C1 and S1 were engaging in a conversation about another staff member. Confidential interviews reported that S1 then made an inappropriate comment, â€œ screw youâ€ to C1. All of the persons interviewed corroborated this information. investigation_findings: On the above date, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Lisa Slusher conducted a complaint inspection for the purpose of resolving the investigation into the above matter. deficiency_1_description: 87089.1	Mental Health (d)	A short-term residential therapeutic program shall provide or ensure access to mental health services, including specialty mental health services and mental health supports that meet short and long term mental and behavioral health goals and treatment as identified by the Qualified Individual, as appropriate to the needs of the child or nonminor dependent in its care.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, a new Therapist has been hired and changes have been made to the schedule to ensure proper coverage.  An email outlining improvements will be sent to LPA by 9/22/22

investigation_findings: On the above date, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Lisa Slusher conducted a complaint inspection for the purpose of resolving the investigation into the above matter. On 8/21/22 S1 had an activity with the youth. During the activity, the staff person allowed a game of "truth or dare" where the dares included licking the floor, drinking a spoonfull of water from the toilet tank, drinking milk with mustard mixed in and wiping their hands underneath the couch and licking their fingers. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted interviews and reviewed documentation. Based on confidential interviews and documentation the allegation is SUBSTANTIATED. investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to inform them that she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. LPA met with Administrator Kamiko Lucas over FaceTime, a video conferencing application. CCL's Investigations Branch Investigator Shannan Borton (IB) investigated this complaint by reviewing incident reports, police reports, client records, and by conducting confidential interviews with the Reporting Party, biological parents, former and current (at the time) clients, and former and current staff on 9/9/2020, 9/14/2020, 9/15/2020, 9/16/2020, 11/5/2020, 11/9/2020, 11/10/2020, and 11/14/2020. Based on IB's interviews and records reviews, IB found that the client had a history of ingesting harmful objects and had other self-injurious behaviors. IB found that the client was not followed right away when she AWOL'd from the facility on 7/18/2020.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 10/12/2022 at --AM. The investigation included: an initial 10-day unannounced complaint investigation inspection was conducted at the facility on 9/15/2022. Facility documents obtained include client rosters, incident reports, and internal investigation. Interviews were conducted with four facility staff and six clients, from 9/13/2022- 10/3/2022. (See LIC 811, dated on 10/12/2022). The allegation is whether Staff 1 brought a vape pen with marijuana to the facility and smoked it while providing supervision. S1 offered the vape pen and was smoked by four clients inside the facilityâ€™s barn. Three staff and four clients confirmed the incident occurred on 9/10/22. S1 admitted to the facility of â€œmaking a mistakeâ€ prior to S1â€™s resignation. S1 also admitted to LPA Johnson of bringing the vape pen to the facility, smoking it, offering it to the youth, and allowing the youth to smoke it in S1â€™s presence.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM) De'jana Crockett, and Administrator Misty Jackson via phone, who assisted with the inspection. The Department's Investigations Branch Investigator (IB) Juan Barajas investigated this complaint by reviewing facility incident reports and the facility's internal investigation report, and by conducting interviews with three clients, three staff, and the Administrator between 4/25/2025 and 8/28/2024. IB made 10 attempts at contact with the staff (S1) related to these allegations between 7/16/2024 and 8/14/2024 with no response from the staff. IB was informed during interviews with two clients that over the course of approximately three months, S1 provided them with marijuana and nicotine to smoke while in care. S1 and the two clients would smoke in the barn area and no other clients were involved. One staff informed IB that they overheard the two clients discussing getting "high" in care during a weekend.

LPA Gonzalez-Soto initiated the investigation with the facility on 12/30/2024 and met with Paige Woodard, Program Director. During the course of the investigation, LPA Ruiz interviewed three youth, one probation officer, and six staff members. LPA reviewed records including: Placement Roster, Training logs, prior complaint history, drug test findings, Serious Incident Reports, and video footage. Regarding the allegations listed, the facility submitted an incident report to the department alleging a staff member provided a marijuana pen to clients and participated in marijuana use with clients. investigation_findings: On April 28, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted a complaint inspection at Muncie Home by phone and spoke with Shayla Taylor, Residential Director. The purpose of the call was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA Barragan, reviewed documents, interviewed staff and Clients. The administrator stated they did discharge C1 from their facility without his belongings. Interviews with Staff and a Client also confirmed this information. Based off interviews and record review the facility did not follow the proper discharge procedures as directed by Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). The Licensee stated that they did not inform C1 that he was being removed from the facility, and they tricked C1 into thinking they were taking him out on an outing. "Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, Division & Chapter number), are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.") Due to the deficiency's listed above two deficiency's are being cited on todays visit. An exit interview was conducted with Shayla Taylor, Residential Director. A copy of the report and appeal rights were emails to Shayla Taylor, Residential Director, in order to obtain a signature.

LPA conducted interviews with four out of six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5), STRTP Administrator(ADM) and one staff (S1). Client #6 (C6) refused to be interviewed. Copies of STRTP Van Event log and STRTP communication log for 3/14/21 were obtained. On March 15, 2021 this agency received allegation that staff #1 (S1) was transporting clients in an unsafe manner on 3/14/21. Confidential interviews disclosed S1 transported clients, while wearing headphones connected to S1â€™s personal cell phone on more than one occasion. Other confidential interviews revealed that on 3/14/21, C1, C2, C3, C6, were left alone in the STRTP van while S1 went into Shoe City. (continued on next page)
deficiency_1_description:
87065.2 (a) (2) Personnel Duties; The facility manager (s) shall meet the requirements of Health & Safety Code section 1522.4 and be responsible for supervising the direct care staff, ensuring appropriate care and supervision is provided to children in accordance with applicable law, licensing regulations and facilities policies. 
This regulation was not met as evidenced byâ€¦
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Per STRTP Administrator, Staff#1 received 7 days of unpaid leave and was retrained by Michelle Hicks in regards to the transporation policy. Remaining STRTP staff will be retrained in April 2021, in regards to the transporation policy

investigation_findings: On May 10, 2022 at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an unannounced visit to New Concept and spoke with Jenaya Norfleet/ Head of Service . The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, a total of three (3) clients and seven (7) staff were interviewed. Confidential interviews reveal a camera was operating in the therapy room used by residents of the facility. Staff and clients admit there was a camera operating during therapy sessions. LPA Phillips observed camera operating from main office computer monitor. There was no audio output from the camera in therapy room. cont on 9099c

On November 29, 2022 at 2:58 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Zena Phillips conducted a follow-up complaint investigation visit to NEW CONCEPT and met with Sueretta Small/ Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to deliver findings for the complaint allegation. Staff not providing adequate supervision. During the investigation of the allegation: LPA Phillips conducted confidential interviews, reviewed documentary evidence: facility files, Special Incident Reports and pictures of staff. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the information gathered produced corroborating evidence to support the above said allegation. LPA Phillips observed photos of staff sleeping at the facility.. cont on 9099 c
deficiency_1_description: 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios(b) a facility with a licensed capacity of seven or more children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows(2) During the hours of 10 pm to 7 am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: LPA advised provider submit written report by 12/16/2022 explaining how facility will prevent staff from sleeping during shift. Licensee reports facility require staff daily assignments & hourly phone in checks by calling corporate office voicemail. Will provide written policy of implemented overnight staff check in. Licensee stated will conduct additional training for staff responsibility/duties.

investigation_findings: On 03/06/2025 at 10:00 AM, LPA Jarmin arrived at New Concept STRTP to discuss the findings of the investigation into staff sleeping during shifts. LPA met with the Office Manager and explained that the investigation concluded on February 12, 2025, at 4:00 PM. During the investigation, LPAs conducted confidential interviews, assessed health and safety conditions, and reviewed relevant documents. The findings confirmed the allegation, showing that the licensee violated staffing ratio requirements for a census of eight children and failed to enforce the facilityâ€™s policy prohibiting sleeping during shifts. Evidence also revealed security and supervision concerns, indicating a failure to ensure proper oversight and protect personal dignity. Based on LPA interviews, record reviews, and evidence obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision is SUBSTANTIATED. Deficiencies are cited to the facility for failure to provide adequate supervision as required by licensing regulations.
deficiency_1_description: 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios(b) a facility with a licensed capacity of seven or more children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows(2) During the hours of 10 pm to 7 am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a written statement by 03/30/2025 to Dennis.Jarmin@dss.ca.gov detailing how the facility will ensure proper supervision for client safety and adherence to facility policies and procedures to prevent similar incidents from recurring.

investigation_findings: On 02/16/2021 at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk met with the Facility Manager (FM), over the phone due to the coronavirus pandemic, for the purpose of delivering findings of this complaint investigation, in regards to the above allegation. Based on all of the interviews conducted, the Department has concluded the above allegation of a Personal Rights violation to be Substantiated, meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Supporting evidence includes the following: In response to a offensive comment by one of the clients, the Facility Manager (FM) admitted to using a curse word in an angry manner, and other clients were witnesses to it. FM also admitted that all staff have cursed at the clients, but try not to. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), the following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC9099-D). Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to FM, in order to obtain FM's signature. Signature will be on file.

investigation_findings: On 12/20/2023 at 1:51pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility, for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation. LPA was met by Facility Manager (FM) who allowed access into the home. The investigation included records review and confidential interviews with, including but not limited to, facility staff members, and clients, as well as residential neighbors to the facility. Based on all interviews conducted, and documents obtained, the Department has found the above allegations to be substantiated, meaning that, the preponderance of the evidence has been met. There was a lack of supervision resulting in loud music being played at 2am and on multiple occasions, causing a disturbance to the community, therefore the finding is substantiated. The facility is issued a citation [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiencies]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were provided to the licensee. (Continued on page LIC9099-D)

investigation_findings: On 11/9/2023 at 10:21am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility, and met with (PM) for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation: The investigation included confidential interviews with, including but not limited to, clients, facility staff members, and administrative staff. The investigation revealed enough evidence to determine that the allegation did take place and was subject to a formal, verbal and written warning to staff (S1) from administrtaive staff. Based on information from record review and confidential interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Licensing Program Analyst has determined a substantiated finding for a violation of personal rights of (C1), therefore the finding is substantiated, thus, posing an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. The facility is issued a citation Type A [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiencies]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, Confidential LIC811, comfidential names list and appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager. (Continued on page LIC9099-D).

investigation_findings: On July 27, 2021 at 10:21 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAâ€™s) Anastasia Flores and Valerie Wilso met with (STRTP) Olive Crest Treatment Center -Saylor House, Residential Manager Brittany Bounds, to deliver the findings on the above allegation. On July 1, 2021 at 10:10 AM, LPA conducted a health and safety inspection of the STRTP and found there were no immediate safety hazards present. However, LPA observed the GH to have less than a dayâ€™s worth of snacks for the clients in care. Copies of STRTP grocery receipts, electronic copies of STRTP menus, client roster, LIC500 and photos of the STRTP food supply were obtained. Interviews were conducted with five of six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5), two staff and facility Administrator. Client #6 (C6) was unavailable at the time of inspection. On June 29, 2021, this agency received allegation that the STRTP did not have adequate food supply available for clients. investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ann Valenzuela contacted Administrator, David Owens on November 10, 2020, for the purpose of delivering findings for the above allegation. Due to COVID 19 a tele-inspection was conducted, LPA met with Administrator, David Owens. The initial complaint inspection of the facility was conducted on April 29, 2020, in which no deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA interviewed five staff {(S1, S2, S3, S4, S5), please refer to confidential names list (LIC 811) dated November 10, 2020}. LPA interviewed three of four clients (C1, C2, C3). Client #4 (C4) was unable to be contacted. LPA reviewed incident report related to C1 and C1â€™s medication distribution log for the month of March 2020. On April 24, 2020, the Department received an allegation that S1 withheld C1â€™s morning medication on March 23, 2020. Confidential interviews and reviewed documents revealed that staff had not dispensed the medication at the normal time due to C1 having a doctorâ€™s appointment for blood work. However, after returning to the facility S1 did not give C1â€™s medication at a later time because C1 was escalated and S1 had advised S5 not to give C1 the medication until C1 had calmed down. CONTINUED ON PAGE 2.

investigation_findings: On 2/16/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint allegations. LPA met with Rachel Gale- Residential Director. LPA McKinley opened the complaint on 8/18/23. The Investigation Branch (IB) conducted the investigation. LPA McKinley conducted a Health and Safety Inspection of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. During the course of the investigation, IB conducted 14 confidential interviews and reviewed documentation, video, photos, texts and law enforcement records. One staff absconded from the facility with a minor in care, across state lines. Interviews were consistent that a staff was found behind closed doors with a client, which is against facility policy. Other behaviors were reported that corroborate an inappropriate relationship between the staff and client at the facility. continued on 9099-C page
deficiency_1_description: Facility is cited per Health and Safety code 1558 (a)(2) Conduct Inimical. (a) The department may prohibit any person from being a member of the board of directors, an executive director, or an officer of a licensee, or a licensee from employing, or continuing the employment of, or allowing in a licensed facility ...., or allowing contact with clients of a licensed facility or... by, any employee, ...... who has:(2) Engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of either the people of this state or an individual in, or receiving services from, the facility or certified family home.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The faciilty will add a policy in the program statment to either move the staff immediately or place them on leave for a period of time,  upon any inclination that an inapproriate relationship is occuring.  The trainer will conduct a class for all staff which covers boundaries, supervision and inapproriate and appropriate conduct with clients.

On 4/29/2021 at 2:05 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley and Stephanie Whitlow met with Administrator Debi Nunez per covid -19 guidelines via video conference on Teams. The purpose of the visit was to deliver complaint investigation findings into the allegation that the Open Line - Westgate staff on duty neglected to supervise youth in care, resulting in clients smoking marijuana or cigarettes at the facility on 1/22/2021. On 2/5/2021 LPA Hall conducted an inspection of the facility with administrator Jesse Hernandez. LPA Hall requested the following documents: Need and Services plans, staffing schedule for January 2021, Incident reports, case notes, staff roster with staff contact information, proof of termination of employee. LPA Hall Found no Title 22 violations during the inspection. Based on LPAâ€™s interviews, which were conducted with the reporting party and co-complainant, the facility administrator and two clients, record reviews, a facility inspection, admission and termination of the employee the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, Division 6, Article 6, Interim Licensing standard (version 3.1 effective 12/8/2020) section 87065.2 (b)(1) is being cited on the attached LIC9099-D. Continued on 9099-C page

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall discussed the findings of this report with Debi Nunes, Administrator, via Microsoft Teams in accordance with COVID-19 precautions. The purpose of the visit was to deliver complaint investigation findings for the allegation. On 3/17/21, LPA completed a health and safety inspection at the facility, interviewed five staff, and reviewed records. Between 3/19/21-4/16/21, LPA interviewed 11 clients, seven staff, and reviewed additional records. The LPA reviewed staff schedules, menu and activity schedules, staff training requirements, vehicle maintenance receipts, Incident reports, personal property inventories, and medical records of clients. The Facility submitted records of initial training for current staff. Staff interviewed reported differing procedures for initial training. Not all staff reported being trained initially with Trauma Informed Care (S2). S8 was unfamiliar with the term Trauma Informed Care. S1 reported being assigned to work in the house on their own on the second day of employment. S4 did not initial their training log. Training records for S5 and S8 arenâ€™t dated. A2 stated he did not provide Trauma Informed Care training for staff, even though it was listed in his job requirements. Continued on 9099-C
deficiency_1_description: â€œTraining of all staff that includes the types of trauma experienced by children and nonminor dependents, the effects and impact of abuse, neglect and trauma, how trauma may manifest itself in daily functioning and behaviors, how to provide care and supervision that is trauma-informed.â€
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Facility will submit proof of Trauma Informed Care training for all staff by 6/14/21.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Katherine Deaton and Kellie McKinley discussed this report with Debi Nunez, Administrator in accordance with COVID-19 precautions on 2/12/2021 via Zoom. The purpose of the visit was to deliver complaint investigation findings into the allegations that the facility did not maintain reporting requirements and facility staff did not provide appropriate care and supervision [specific to education]. The Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) contacted four facility staff, three clients, two County Social Workers, one school official, one probation officer, and conducted reviewed records. On 10/27/2020, LPA Deaton contacted Alisha Endecott, former County Social Worker (CSW1) for C1 (see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 10/30/20) who stated she received voicemails regarding some incidents but never received a written incident report. LPA Deaton also contacted a school staff (SS) who provided the LPA with the School Attendance Record and stated C1â€™s classes start at 8:30am. On 10/30/2020, LPA Chad Cabigon contacted Amy Claxton, Field Supervisor (S2) who stated C1 would usually log in for a few moments and then say, â€œMr. So-and-so dismissed us already,â€ but that the facility would then get calls from school saying C1 logged off after saying he had an appointment at the facility. S2 stated that she observed C1 sign on to the online classes but would listen to music and not pay attention to the class. This report is continued on the attached LIC9099-C.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall arrived at the agency on 07/26/21 and met with Debi Nunes and Tyson Poso, Administrators, to deliver investigation findings for this complaint. The Investigations Branch (IB) Investigator Nancy Saechao investigated the complaint allegation that staff (S1, see confidential names list titled 7/26/21) smoked marijuana with minor. IB conducted interviews with two witnesses, seven current residents, two previous residents, five current facility staff and one previous facility staff. IB also reviewed resident Face Sheets, incident reports, facility Personnel Report, staff schedules, resident roster, residentsâ€™ Needs and Services Treatment Plans, and staff training records. Consistent statements in interviews indicate that S1 smoked marijuana with residents. Four of the interviewees stated they participated or observed S1 smoking marijuana with the residents. Other interviews indicated they had heard about S1 providing and or smoking marijuana with the minors. S1 denied smoking marijuana, but admitted to facilitating the purchase of marijuana for the residents on multiple occasions. S1 also stated that he/she allowed approximately nine residents to smoke marijuana in the home 25-30 times. Continued on 9099C
met_with: Debi Nunes and Tyson Poso, Administrators
deficiency_1_description: Health and Safety Code 1550(c): Conduct Inimical: "The Department may deny an application for, or suspend or revoke any license...for any of the following grounds: Conduct which is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety...of an individual in, or receiving services from the facilityâ€¦â€
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee terminated S1 on 9/16/20. Licensee provided LPA with termination letter.  Plan of correction has been completed.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Rachel Underwood- Residential Director. LPA McKinley conducted the complaint investigation. LPA opened the investigation with the facility on 9/26/24 and conducted a Health and safety inspection of the facility. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed five minors, a Head of Services, an administrator, a Facility manager, direct care staff, a residential director, a county social worker and the reporting party. LPA reviewed records from the facility including: Staff schedules, Placement Roster, Serious Incident Reports, CFT notes, and Needs and Service Plans for foster youth. It was alleged that staff speak inappropriately to minors and were involved in a verbal altercation in the presence of minors in care. Interviews and documentation were consistent that one evening, staff were overheard arguing and swearing with each other and to the youth.

On January 28, 2025, at 3:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin arrived at OUR HEALING CENTER Facility and met with Administrator, Maricela Romero Rodriguez, to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. On July 16, 2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging drug activity and an alleged sexual assault occurring on facility premises. It was reported that since January 1, 2024, local law enforcement has responded to Our Healing Center facility multiple times indicating that on at least four occasions, staff reported they were unable to control their clients. The reported allegations were referred to CCLD Investigations Branch assigned to Investigator, Dennis Douglas. On July 23, 2024, LPA Regina Martin conducted the initial complaint notification, met with Administrator, and obtained requested documents. The investigation further included review of client files, incident reports and review of facility file history as well as, review of Santa Barbara County Sheriffâ€™s incident reports. In addition, confidential interviews were conducted with six youth residents, five staff members, Administrator, and contacts with the Santa Barbara Sheriffâ€™s Department (Continued on page 9099-C)

On 2/22/23 at 1:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at listed facility and spoke with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, interviews were conducted, and incident reports were reviewed, and it was determined that minors engaged in inappropriate behavior while in care and had access to alcohol. Based on LPAâ€™s interview with staff, clients, and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation, Minors engaged in inappropriate behavior while in care and minors had access to alcohol is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. No citations were given due to facility following their emergency intervention protocol and having a safety plan set in place. At this time, no deficiencies was given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager.

On 5/24/22 at 1:08PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint inspection at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. During complaint investigation, LPA inspected the facility and interviewed 4 residents and 2 staff. Based on observation and interview, 2 of 4 residents reported seeing bugs in the facility. Photos of 3 different bugs on different occasions inside the facility were sent to LPA, including at least two where bugs were found in a resident's bed. During one observation, LPA was called by a resident, and LPA could hear staff remove the bug as requested by the youth. Additionally, LPA was initially informed by the facility that the facility had a current contract with an exterminator service. However, upon request for the most recent invoice, LPA was provided with a new contract dated 5/6/22, after LPA's intial inspection on 5/4/22. SEE NEXT PAGE.

investigation_findings: On 9/7/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on record review, physical evidence obtained during the investigation, and confidential interviews with residents and staff, the facility has food in the quantity to meet the residents' needs but has not been following the menu, menus as served were not available for review because they were not being updated as served, and facility receipts provided from 8/18/22 to 8/23/22 reflect that five (5) visits were made in that time to fast food restaurants, and on at least two days, multiple visits were made in the same day. Based on the amount spent, not all residents were fed fast food meals on these occasions, but as stated above, no menus as served were available to review. Additionally, based on physical evidence and confidential interviews, multiple facility staff are disrespectful to residents and use abusive language toward residents.

investigation_findings: On 12/14/22 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at listed facility and spoke with Mattie Marsh/Patrick Davis, Administrators and Bryce Marsh, House Manager.
