investigation_findings: At 02:00PM on 10/23/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karmen Balhotra made an unannounced complaint inspection to the facility listed above. The reason for the inspection is to deliver findings for the allegation listed above. LPA met Brice Marsh, Supervisor who helped facilitate the inspection. Over the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and a file review. Evidence obtained revealed that for the allegation of, Minor inappropriately touched another minor while in care, is found to be substantiated. During confidential interviews, three of four staff members interviewed stated that a former client did inappropriately touch another client in care. Confidential interviews revealed that staff were unaware of sexualized behaviors that the client may have had and that the incident took place after clients were leaving the facility together on unauthorized absences. The facility separated clients upon learning of the incident. Therefore, per evidence obtained, the preponderance of evidence has been met. Based on todayâ€™s inspection the facility is being cited under section 80072(a)(1) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Supervisor.

investigation_findings: On 03/20/2024 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno and LPA Shikya Belfield made an unannounced visit to initiate a complaint investigation at Palo Verde House to deliver the findings on the listed allegation. LPA Cardeno and LPA Belfield met with Tony Beane, Facility Manager. During the course of the investigation, LPA Cardeno and LPA Belfield toured the facility, conducted confidential interviews, and had documentation including photo evidence of the refrigerator being locked up and not being accessible for the clients in care. Based on confidential interviews and supportive documentation that include but not limited to photographs the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, the allegation, â€œStaff did not ensure food was accessible to minor in careâ€ is substantiated. Food service regulation 87076(c)(1), is being cited on the attached LIC9099-D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Tony Beane, Facility Manager, whose signature on this form confirms receipt of these documents. Appeal rights were given to the facility.

deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to immediately cease using a lock on the refrigerator and will submit a plan to the department regarding how they will maintain safe  and accessible food supply for all clients in care. Plan to be submitted to the department by the plan of correction due date of 4/21/2024.

investigation_findings: On Tuesday 4/20/21 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver complaint investigation findings. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was conducted as a televisit. LPA met with Executive Director Maritza Jefferson and informed of the purpose of this visit. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with director and involved resident and reviewed the incident report for the incident in question, medication documentation, and training documentation. Based on interviews and record review, on 5/28/20, staff S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 4/20/21) was preparing medication for administration to two youth by placing their medications in cups. Staff called youth to come and take their medication. While S1 was waiting for the youth, S1 continued preparing the medication. Youth R1 walked up and took the cup of medication on the table that S1 had already prepared but which was for another youth. S1 did not see this and handed R1 their cup of medication, which R1 took. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne spoke with Laynee Kuhn on 11-9-20 at 10:33 a.m.to deliver the finding of the above allegation. During this investigation some copies of documents obtained from the agency include an initial needs and services plan and progress notes. The reporting party was interviewed on 5-12-20, the facility social worker was interviewed on 7-29-20 and the youth was interviewed on 8-11-20 (see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 5-11-20). It was alleged that the facility staff did not follow childâ€™s needs and services plan by not providing weekly therapy sessions with the facility social worker. According to documents between the time period of 8-5-19 to 6-5-20, the youth refused to meet with the facility social worker six times. On 3-24-20, the facility social worker attempted to contact the youth but did not get a response. On 2-25-20 it was decided that the youth would start having bi-weekly therapy sessions. According to the youth, one or two therapy sessions were held at the facility with the facility social worker. Documents indicate that some sessions took place in the community. The facility social worker was on modified duty from 8-16-19 until 9-6-19 but it is not documented if anyone else provided therapy for the youth. There is not any documentation of therapy for the month of September 2019. The initial needs and services plan dated 8-5-19 was provided to this LPA from the agency. The needs and services plan should be updated every thirty days. The agency was unable to provide an updated needs and services. Based on the information gathered during this investigation the allegation is substantiated. Facility cited for violation of Title 22, Interim Licensing Standards version 3.1 regulation 87068.3(a) Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC811 were sent via email to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director.
deficiency_1_description:
87068.3(a) Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan. The needs and services plan shall be updated at least every 30 days...
this requirement was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Executive Director stated that all areas of the N&S plan will be addressed on a 30 day basis. Paradise Oaks Youth Services has already put in place a facility social worker will be reassigned to provide therapy for a client if the regular facility social worker is out on leave for any reason. POYS will develop a procedure to update the N&S plan monthly and/or when services are modified. Executive Director will send procedures and amendment to their Program Statement to LPA Horne on or prior to 12-9-20.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne, met with Laynee Kuhn via MS Teams on 11-9-20 at 10:40 a.m. to deliver the finding of the above allegation. During this investigation a virtual inspection of the facility was conducted on 7-27-20. Some copies of documents obtained include needs and services plan for the FY (see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 7-27-20) incident reports dated 3-3-20. Interviews were as follows: FY was interviewed on 8-26-20; the intake social worker on 9-10-20; facility administrator on 9-17-20 and a former staff on 10-29-20. It was alleged that staff engaged in a verbal altercation with FY. According to the intake social worker FY had thrown grapes at a staff because the staff would not give the phone to FY. The intake social worker observed the staff person get close to FYâ€™s face and at first thought the two were joking around until the intake social worker saw the look on the staff personâ€™s face. The intake social worker told the staff to step outside and take a breath. According to FY the staff did get in his face. The staff person did admit to being angry and stated he did get into FYâ€™s face and told FY he wanted to hit him. According to documentation the incident took place on 3-3-20 and the staff person resigned on 3-4-20. Based on the information gathered during the course of this investigation the allegation is substantiated. Facility cited for violation of Tilte 22 Division Six STRTP Interim Licensing Standards version 3.1 regulation 87072(10) Personal Rights. Exit interview conducted , a copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC811 were sent to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director via email on 11-9-20.

to be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement wa not met as evidenced by:

investigation_findings: On Tuesday October 19, 2021 @ 3:30PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a Tele-Inspection regarding complaint allegation listed above. LPA Landry spoke with Facility Representative listed above. This investigation initially began 09/07/2021, since then more information has been received. On or around May 30, 2020, child #1 was outside of the facility while two other clients (child 2 and 3) were inside of facility with staff #2. While staff #3 prepared medication in the detached garage/office area staff #2 was designated to supervise these three clients. Staff #2 was inside the facility maintaining visual supervision of clients 2 and 3 while sitting near the front door looking/ listening for child #1, who was outside in the adjacent frontyard driveway playing basketball. It is unclear how much time passed when staff #2 conducted a routine head check and child #1 was not located. Runaway Procedures were executed. A Missing Persons Report was filed and pertinent parties notified. Child #1 never returned to the facility. Based on LPA Landry's observation and interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the above allegation is found to be Substantiated per ----->

investigation_findings: On 11/22/2024, at 01:17 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit at Plan It Life Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Administrator Jesse Jorrin to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above. On 09/11/2024, Community Care Licensing received allegation that staff choked a minor while in care. investigation_findings: On April 14, 2025, at 11:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong and LPM Enrique Hernandez made an unannounce visit at the above said facility, and met with the Executive Assistant Manager Amanda Tobar, who granted access into the facility. investigation_findings: On 05/03/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a follow up complaint inspection for Quality Family Services - Clinton and spoke with Laura Romero. Based upon the content of the interviews and documents reviewed, it was determined that due to an emergency 1 of the 2 staff working had to leave. This caused a lapse in supervision of the clients in care which resulted in a client hitting another client causing injury. Based on the above, there is a preponderance of evidence to conclude that the allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. This report along with appeals rights was left with Ms. Romero.

investigation_findings: On January 20, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce, conducted a telephonic Complaint Inspection in compliance with COVID-19 Pandemic restrictions. Based on the information obtained during the course of the investigation, it has been determined the above allegation is Substantiated. Based on record review, along with interviews of clients and staff it was determined that a client had gained access to the staff office while a staff member was using the office restroom and had left the office door unlocked. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA discovered the client had been administered a medication increase, based on the psychiatristâ€™s proposed medication plan, without the Courts approval of the new JV-223. investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Whitlow, conducted complaint investigation for the allegation stating, â€œClient received inappropriate discipline from staff,â€ and â€œStaff touched client in care inappropriately.â€ LPA, Kellie McKinley, conducted initial complaint opening inspection. facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to let them know that she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. LPA met with Administrator Christine Gwin over the phone. LPA investigated this complaint by conducting interviews with the Reporting Party, 30 clients, and 7 staff on 2/24/2021, 2/25/2021, 2/26/2021, 3/3/2021, 3/4/2021, 3/24/2021, 3/25/2021, and 3/26/2021. LPA also reviewed the facility's Discipline and Runaway policy/procedures, Incident Reports, staff training records, and emergency intervention training materials. During interviews, all clients, except for three stated that as a consequence of AWOL'ing, clients' shoes and extra clothing are taken from them upon return from AWOL. Two of those three clients who did not state this, just did not know what happens upon return from AWOL. LPA learned that clients who have AWOL'd have their jackets, sweat pants, extra clothes, and shoes taken from them, including personal clothes. In general, clients have a uniform they wear to school and during free time and are allowed to wear personal clothing after nightly showers, and on weekends.
deficiency_1_description: Personal Rights. Each child...is accorded the personal rights...including the personal right to be provided with and allowed to possess and use adequate personal items...which includes...clothing items.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Starting immediately no clothing nor shoes will be taken from clients. By POC due date of 3/31/2021, Administrator will submit her plan for preventing AWOL's in a different way.
deficiency_2_description: General Provisions. STRTP staff may be justified in using restraints as an emergency intervention if...the restraint is reasonably applied to prevent a child exhibiting assaultive behavior from exposure to injury or danger to self or others.
deficiency_2_plan_of_correction: Administrator will re-train staff on appropriate physical interventions. Administrator will tell LPA the date this training will occur on by POC due date of 3/31/2021. Administrator will submit the sign in sheet to LPA

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
investigation_findings: On 10/01/2021, at approximately 2 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon delivered the findings for this complaint investigation. LPA was met by Program Director Chris Essary and the report was discussed. LPA investigated the allegation that there was an overall Lack of Supervision of youths. On 06/25/20201 and 08/20/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted unannounced onsite inspections of this facility, interviewing staff and youth residents on both occasions. Records obtained and reviewed were the following: Needs & Services Plans for the referenced youths, the facilityâ€™s placement log or history of minor clients and a roster of facility staffers who worked for the time period of interest, a San Bernardino County Juvenile Probation Department STRTP Investigation Report dated 10/21/2020, and personnel files including documentation of the remedial training agreed upon as part of the corrective plan of action articulated in the aforementioned report. Interviews were conducted with the following individuals: three current student youth clients, a current ROP staffer, a former ROP employee, two involved Probation Officers (one from San Bernardino County, and one from Kern), and a biological mother to a former youth resident.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
investigation_findings: On 7/6/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver findings for a complaint with allegations of â€œChildren are not provided a safe environment.â€ LPA met with Paige Woodard, Deputy Director, and discussed the above allegation. During the investigation, LPA Ignacia Villapudua-Soto toured the facility with Deputy Director, Paige Woodard on 2/17/22. On this inspection, LPA Villapudua-Soto informed Deputy Director, Paige Woodard that LPA Jean Stidman would be investigating this complaint and would request documentation via email. On 2/28/22 and 3/1/22 LPA Stidman obtained documentation for the complaint investigation of clientâ€™s daily schedule, clients monthly activity schedule, staff work schedules for January and February 2022, staff time sheets dated 1/13/22-2/9/22, staffing procedure documentation, and ROP Regional Director letter. LPA conducted seven interviews regarding the complaint. Confidential interviews and record review revealed the facility was out of compliance with direct care staff/child ratios. -Continued on 9099-C-
deficiency_1_description: Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. In a facility with a licensed capacity of seven or more children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm: When there are five or more children present at the facility, there shall be at least one awake and on duty direct care for every four children, or fraction thereof, present at the facility. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The facility will create a new schedule with staff increasing hours and other facility staff are transferring to ratio staff.  Facility will also train staff to notify office immidiately when out of ratio to get assistance.  Facility will provide licensing a copy of the schedule and signed training by 7/8/22.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill was at the facility on 5/20/2022 at 4:40 PM when the complaint for this incident came in. On July 21, 2021 at 12pm LIcensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility to deliver finidings from the above allegation. LPA met with Raven Morrow, Facility Manager. There was photo of the neighbor's broken window and an invoice provided for the repairs to LPA. As a result, the allegation is Substantiated. Facility is being Cited for violation of 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratio's (a) In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: (1) During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection at the facility on 8/17/21 at 10:30 AM but nobody was home. LPA then went to the administrative/nonpublic school location in Minden, Nevada and met with the administrator, Tracy Edwards. Interview with S1 (see LIC811 dated 8/17/21) on 8/17/21 demonstrates that S2 was aware of a bear leaving the property about 6:30 AM after having accessed the trash bins and caused the trash to be strung out in front of the facility and across the street. S1 states they received a text from S2 stating C1 (who is no longer residing in the facility) had taken out the trash the night prior as part of their chore and had not secured the trash bin as required to prevent wildlife from accessing the trash bin. S2 told S1 that C1 needed to clean up the trash themselves as they were at fault for it being left accessible to the bear. S2, being the newer staff, did not clean up the mess left behind by the bear until C1 woke up and was taken outside to clean up the mess, two hours later. Administrator arrived to the facility at approximately 9:30 AM to find S1 and C1 outside cleaning up the mess left by the bear, including the trash that was taken across the street.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced complaint inspection on 8/5/25 at 11:00 AM and met with Peter Woods, Administrator, to discuss the findings of the complaint allegation. LPA Hill informed Mr. Woods that the complaint investigation included an initial inspection to the facility on 7/9/25 and collateral inspection conducted on 7/18/25 where youth and staff were interviewed. The allegation that staff are not providing adequate supervision to minors engaging in inappropriate activities is related to an incident involving two youth smoking while on the facility grounds on 6/21/25. The agency was alerted via email within the hour of the youth being seen smoking and conducted a search of the area where the youth were allegedly seen but found no cigarettes or evidence of other items being smoked.

deficiency_2_plan_of_correction: The facility shall provide proof of training related to reporting requirements by the POC date indicated.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele inspection on 11/02/2020 at 1:00 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Administrator to discuss the findings of this complaint investigation. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the investigation included a health and safety inspection conducted on 8/25/20 and included interviews with four youth and one staff person who were present. Additional investigation included interviews with complainant on 8/20/20, three additional staff and four youth and review of documentation obtained from the facility from 8/26/20 to 10/18/20. The complaint alleges that a lack of supervision resulted in an inappropriate interaction between youth in that one youth was able to leave his own room undetected after lights out and be in another youth's room where a fight broke out between the two youth as a result of the alleged inappropriate interaction. During confidential interviews, it was not clear what inappropriate interaction took place between the two youth prior to staff responding to the sounds of fighting coming from the room.

investigation_findings: At 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Singh-Sood traveled to the home above for the purpose of conducting an unannounced complaint investigation inspection. LPA met with __ in person and Devorah Weiss by telephone, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 2 ambulatory clients. On 02/08/2023, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Evolve Treatment Centers Walnut Creek with one allegation: "Minors are left without supervision." This complaint was assigned to and investigated by LPA Fremont. Based on records review and interviews with staff and clients that show the facility has been utilizing a 1:6 staff-to-child ratio instead of the 1:3 ratio noted in the Licensee"s Plan of Operation, and reports that there was at least one incident when clients were left without staff at the facility for at least 30 minutes during a staff medical emergency, the allegation "Facility does not have adequate staffing" is found to be substantiated. A deficiency was cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section 80022(k) - Plan of Operation. Please see attached LIC9099-D for details.
deficiency_1_description: 80022(k) Plan of Operation: The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:Based on records review and interview  with staff and clients, between
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: By 11:59PM on 8/15/2023, the facility shall submit a plan to either amend their Plan of Operation to show a 1:6 staff/child ration, or shall submit a new plan for staff recruitment and any efforts put forth to hire and retain new staff.

investigation_findings: On 9/6/2023 at 11:38AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of the visit was to deliver the finding for the above allegation. LPA met with Elijah Aquilina, Residential Counselor. LPA initially closed this complaint as unsubstantiated on 8/4/2023. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted twelve confidential interviews. LPA reviewed C1 and C2's treatment plans, shift notes for 7/21/2023-7/22/2023, incident reports, and facility's program statement. Based on confidential interviews, C1 and C2 did engage in sexual behaviors in the facility. Based on confidential interviews, three of the four interviewed remembered the door being open at the time. The same three interviewees had stated that the interaction happened in about 15-minutes. Based on confidential interviews, the sexual behavior happened during "hygiene" time between 9-10PM before the 15-minute checks are conducted between 10PM-6AM.

facility_name: FRED FINCH YOUTH CENTER - NEW YOSEMITE
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and Lisette Valenzuela conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Fred Finch and met with Rising Oaks administrator Kelli Knox and Avolon administrator Grace Helton. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating this allegations, LPA Belfield conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentation to include but not limit email communications and incident reports. It was determined that the program did not give proper notice when evicting the client from the program and failed to pick them up from the hospital. The propinderance of evidence has been met, therefore this allegation is Substantiated. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with apeal rights will be sent to Adminsitrator Kellie Knox.

On July 10, 2025 at 10:15AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Justine Armstrong and Aimee Moratalla conducted an unannounced visit to the FTBP - Opportunities Home for Children to deliver their investigation findings. LPA J. Armstrong met with the Administrator Audrey Hughes, and together they discussed the findings. On May 16, 2025, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging the following incidents involving the care of a minor: 1. Staff handled the minor roughly 2. Staff locked the minor outside the facility for an extended period 3. Staff yelled at the minor 4. The staff's behavior poses a risk to minors in care. During the investigation, LPA J. Armstrong conducted confidential interviews and reviewed relevant documents. After evaluating all statements and information gathered, the allegations were substantiated. The evidence confirmed that the minor (C1) was handled roughly by being locked outside the facility by staff member S2. (Continued on LIC 9099C)

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewed all involved staff, clients and witnesses. LPA Jones-Steward reviewed intake assessment and treatment plan for C1. Clients and Staff both report that staff were unaware that the clients AWOLED or that C1 did not return. Both staff persons who were interviewed stated that they did not notice that clients were missing until the next morning when the mother of one of the clients called to report that her daughter was i the hospital. Both staff stated that they overlooked reporting the hospitalization to Community Care Licensing.. Based on the available information, the above allegations are substantiated. Substantiated means that there is a preponderance of evidence that an allegtion is true. Facility was cited for Lack of Supervision (80078) and failure to meet Reporting Requirements.(80061)

investigation_findings: On 10/01/2024 at 10:15 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith investigated the above allegations. LPA and LPM interviewed involved staff and clients. LPA and LPM also conducted a walk-through inspection of the facility on 9/16/24. Interview evidence revealed a lack of a monthly written and posted menu since the facility chef resigned on 8/15/24. Since then clients are being required to participate in meal preparation for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.Interview statements reveal that some staff do assist clients in preparing some of their daily meals. During the walk-through LPA and LPM observed a crack in a bedroom door, a kitchen cabinet without a door, and an exit sign hanging loosely from the celling. Based on the available information LPA and LPM gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegations are found to be substantiated. Continued on next page. (see 9099 C).

investigation_findings: On 11/7/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Juvy Golub and Facility Manager Rahanat Abubakar and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the visit, confidential interviews with 7 staff were conducted. LPA attempted an interview of the involved reseident, but due to limited verbal/communication, LPA was unable to obtain a statement. All other residents are nonverbal. Based on staff interviews, the resident likes when staff pat the resident's face due to a skin-picking condition the resident has that results in the skin itching but not being safe to scratch. LPA reviewed the involved resident's records and observed medical records reflecting the skin-picking behavior. SEE PAGE 2

investigation_findings: On 6/21/2022 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Heiwa House and spoke with Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager (FM). The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, shift logs and client files were reviewed, and it was determined that, staff at the facility does not supervise visits or ensure that minor has transportation back to the facility after visits. Based on a review of the facilities Program Statement under Transportation, it says, â€œResidents will be transported to and from social, recreational, and religious activities in the program vehicleâ€. In the description of consumer service section of the Program Statement, it says that they provide â€œBasis General Services and Personal Servicesâ€. On the Basis General Services, it says that the facility will â€œPlan, arrange and/ or provide transportation for home/day passes.â€ During confidential interviews, it was confirmed that the facility was not providing transportation to and from home visits. It was disclosed that minor in care uses uber to get to and from monthly visits with their family. Since facility staff do not transport minor to his monthly visits, they do not supervise minor to ensure they are safe. ------CONT. ON 9099C-----

investigation_findings: On 6/21/22 at 11:08 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Heiwa House and spoke with Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, needs and service plans and incident reports were reviewed, and it was determined that a minor sustained injuries in care and staff did not properly care for minorâ€™s injury. During a facility inspection dated 5/18/2022, LPA Ng took pictures of clientâ€™s arm and surrounding areas when they arrived home from school. LPA also received pictures from witnesses. The observed wound was a one inch in size, vertical on their left arm, and it was a dark red color in the middle and brown scabbing around the wound. Surrounding the wound were healed scrapes. The healed scrapes were circular and had a dark brown tint. investigation_findings: On 9-13-22, 1:50 PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) George Karkazis and Alyssa NG conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Heritage House II and met with Alfredo Bonafacio, Facility Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings of the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff members. All clients at this facility are nonverbal. Therefore, LPA was unable to interview clients. However, LPA Karkazis conducted interviews with authorized representatives. In addition, LPA Karkazis obtained and reviewed documentation that pertained to the above allegations. On August 11, 2022, there was a staff note stating that (S3) (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated 9/7/2022, was informed by House Manager (S4) that direct care worker (S5) had locked a client in their bedroom using a child safety lock on the outside of his door. Based on interviews, it was learned that the (S5) had difficulty with the clientâ€™s behavior and made an error in judgment. In addition, LPA obtained a copy of the incident report dated August 18, 2022, mentioning that a direct care worker (S5) used a child safety lock on a clientâ€™s bedroom door. On August 12, 2022, the staff member was terminated. Based on interviews and physical evidence, it was determined that the Staff locked the minor in the minor's bedroom, and the minor had an inappropriate locking device on the outside of the minor's bedroom door. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility, and deficiencies were cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84072(14) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Alfred Bonafacio.

To not be locked in any room, building, or facility premises at any time.

deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee shall have a training session 9-19-22, training staff that the use of door locking devices are prohibited.  Licensee will provide a training handout to staff regarding procedures.  Due  Friday 9-23-22:  Training hand out, staff attendees, signatures, and shift notes reflecting the training.

investigation_findings: On 02/09/2024 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, met with Operations Manager/Facility Manager, Victor Hamaker, to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation at Hillside Horizon Group Home (GH). On 02/15/2023 at 3:30 PM, LPA conducted an inspection of the facility, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with the administrator (ADM), facility manager (FM), and recruiting manager (RM). LPA reviewed LIC 500, Guardian roster report, and staff files. On October 31, 2022, the Department received a complaint that alleged that uncleared staff are providing care and supervision. Specifically, it was alleged that multiple staff are not cleared to work at the facility. Regarding the allegation that uncleared staff are providing care and supervision, record review of staff files and confidential interviews revealed that staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), and staff 3 (S3) did not have a criminal record clearance. (See LIC 811 dated 02/09/2024). ***********Confidential*************

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez conducted a complaint inspection, via telephone, (in accordance with PIN 20-05-CRP) and spoke with Administrator, Sylvia Smith. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA conducted a record review, and conducted interviews with two clients and six staff. LPA also conducted an interview with the Program Manager, with Oakland Unified School District (OUSD) and obtained supporting documentation. The documentation obtained from OUSD indicates that C1 was enrolled in school on March 10, 2020; however, was deactivated on June 30, 2020, due to being a â€œno show.â€ The facility manger at the time stated C1 was not enrolled and was unable to provide LPA with supporting documentation regarding C1â€™s school enrollment. Based on documentation received, LPA's interviews which were conducted, and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. Interim Licensing Standards are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator for a signature. A copy of appeal rights was also provided to the facility.

investigation_findings: On 11/10/2020 at 1:00 p.m., due to COVID 19, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez contacted Program Representative Marissa Jones of San Diego Center for Children and conducted a tele-inspection to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. On 11/21/19, at 09:00 a.m., LPA Lopez initiated the investigation at the facility. During the investigation, LPA Lopez conducted confidential interviews with one client, four staff, one administrator, and reviewed incident reports. On 11/14/2019, the Department received an allegation that facility staff inappropriately restrained client #1 (C1). The report indicated that staff placed C1 in a supine hold, staff reported the hold over walkie talkie, and staff were told to "abort" the hold due to C1 not being allowed to be placed in a supine hold. Confidential interviews stated Staff #1, Staff #2 and Staff #3 placed C1 in a supine hold for five seconds. Staff reported the hold over the walkie talkie and nursing staff immediately responded to transition C1 to a seated hold due to C1 having a restriction against the supine hold. (see continuation form LIC 9099C dated 11/10/20)
deficiency_1_description: 87072(d) (11)The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.:To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction:
S1 was given a corrective action for conducting and directing a restricted hold on C1 and not reporting the incident. 

S1 terminated employment on 03/29/2020.  
Facility added measures to post client restriction information on a board visible for staff in the cottages.

investigation_findings: On 05/27/2021 at 1:30 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Program Representative Michelle Pechtl of San Diego Center for Children to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. On 12/29/2020 at 3:25 p.m, due to COVID 19, LPA met with Program Administrator Ervey Salinas via tele-inspection to initiate complaint investigation and conducted a safety check; no safety hazards observed. During the investigation, LPA Lopez conducted confidential interviews with three staff (S1, S2, S3), one administrator, one client (C1) and reviewed incident report. On 12/22/2020, the Department received an allegation that S1 mismanaged child's medication. It was reported that C1 was lethargic at the facility and was taken to the hospital. Confidential interviews stated S1 gave C1 an incorrect dose of medication and S1 contacted the doctor and nurse supervisor for instructions due to the error. (see continuation form LIC9099-C dated 05/27/2021)
deficiency_1_description: ILS 87075(c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(11).
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Licensee stated C1â€™s dosage was changed from liquid form to pill form. S1 was given a corrective action, and re-training. Licensee provided copies of documented training and corrrective action.

investigation_findings: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian met with Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator Yasmin Williams to discuss the investigative findings for the above allegation. LPA Carol Anderson conducted an inspection to the STRTP on March 24, 2022 at 2:03PM. No immediate hazards observed. LPA reviewed and requested facility and client records. On March 24, 2022, Community Care Licensing received information alleging that Staff #1 (see LIC811 dated 03/14/2023) pushed minor #2 (see LIC811 dated 03/14/2023) while in care. Confidential interviews with two staff revealed that the minor was pushed by the staff while multiple witnesses were present. Documentation was received of three written witness statements. Confidential interviews confirm that the staff member #S1 did push the minor in care. The minor was unable to be interviewed at this time although multiple attempts were made. LPA received consistent confidential information and documentation that the allegation occurred. Based on interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that the staff #1 pushed the minor #2 while in care is substantiated. This posed an immediate health and safety risk to the children placed in care. These actions are in violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 4, Article 6, 87072(c) Personal Rights. See attached LIC 9099D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided. Due to technical difficulties with printing the report, the report was scanned and emailed to the licensee.

investigation_findings: On August 29, 2023, at 12:36 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted an unannounced complaint inspection. During the investigation, LPA Jauregui obtained incident reports, client roster, C1's needs and services plan, C1's safety plan, staff schedule, and staff contact information. LPA conducted three staff interviews (S1-S3) and reviewed SIR dated 3/29/23. On April 4, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received the allegation that facility staff handled minor in a rough manner and facility staff inappropriately restrained minor causing injury. Confidential interviews indicated while C1 was climbing a fence, S4 and S6 initiated a hold by placing their hands on C1s shoulders, S2 and S5 placed their hands on C1s legs to prevent C1 from climbing any further, S4 removed C1s hands from the fence causing C1 to fall back and hit their head. This procedure was not in compliance with Safe and Positive Approaches.

investigation_findings: On November 5, 2020 at 2:40 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Anastasia Flores met with Santa Maria Group Home (GH) Administrator, Francine Haynes via tele-visit to deliver the finding of the above allegation. On September 23, 2020 at 11:52 AM, LPA Flores conducted a safety inspection of the GH and no safety concerns or hazards were observed. Copies of staff and client rosters were obtained. Interviews were conducted with three out of four clients, GH Administrator (ADM), GH director (DIR) staff #1, #2 (S1, S2) and two San Bernardino County Social Workers. Client #4 refused to be interviewed. On September 15, 2020 this agency received allegation that ADM would allow her 13-year-old biological child (C1) to visit the GH several days a week. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 is in the GH about two hours a day sometimes more with the clients in care. C1 can observe and listen to staff interact with all clients of the facility when C1 is present, including personal and confidential information. Other confidential interviews revealed that C1 attends the same school with at least one of the clients in the GH and C1 will play games or sometimes assist clients with their homework. (continued on next page)

investigation_findings: On December 28, 2023 at 2:15 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of a complaint investigation to the facility. The LPA met with Administrator, Kenneth Calvin. On August 30, 2023, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegation. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: four clients - Ref. #1 and 3 at the facility on September 21, 2023, Ref. #2 at school on October 6, 2023, Ref. #4 at their new placement on November 7, 2023; the Administrator via telephone on September 22, 2023 and December 19, 2023; Facility Manager Ref. #6 via telephone on December 28, 2023. On several occasions with no success, the LPA attempted to contact the Facility Manager, Ref. #5, who terminated their employment at the facility. The LPA reviewed two videos of the assault, a Termination Report, a Debriefing, and incident reports. The investigation revealed two videos of a physical altercation between Facility Manager Ref. #5 and Ref. #2, 11 years old, at the facility. It revealed that at least one client, Ref. #1 was a witness and recorded the video. The investigation revealed that Ref. #2 did not suffer injuries, marks or bruises due to the altercation.

investigation_findings: On March 7, 2023, at 11:53am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Administrator Ethan Alli of Southcoast-Caladium to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. LPA conducted an inspection with the facility on October 25, 2022, at 1:16pm, no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA interviewed three facility staff (S1, S2, S3), one county social worker (CSW), and four children (C1, C2, C3, C4). LPA also reviewed Medication Administration Record (MAR) for C1 for October of 2022. On October 20, 2022, the Department received an allegation that staff are not administering medications according to physician's orders. It was reported that the facility is not giving C1 their prescribed medications. A review of the facilityâ€™s MAR for C1 during October of 2022 revealed that C1â€™s medications were not given from 10/10/2022-10/14/2022. Confidential interviews revealed that facility staff did not ensure that C1â€™s prescriptions were refilled in time so that C1 would not miss a dosage. Cont. on 9099-C

investigation_findings: On October 8, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Natasha Dunlap met with Qoodseya Afredi, South Coast Childrenâ€™s Society Facility Administrator to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegations. LPA Adrian Mendez initiated the complaint at the facility on 7/16/20 at 11:17am and no immediate safety concerns were noted. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator Jesse Vargas of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. The investigation included interviews with three clients (C1, C2, C3), two staff (S1, S2), Facility Manager, County Social Worker and Detective with Costa Mesa Police Department. County records, investigative history, client records and Police Report were reviewed. On July 6, 2020, CCL received a complaint regarding neglect/lack of care and supervision resulting in sexual abuse of C1. Information obtained from confidential interviews and evidence gathered corroborated the allegations of lack of care and supervision resulting in sexual abuse of C1. During the investigation, confidential interviews revealed numerous incidents of sexual behaviors between C1 and C2. next page...

This requirement was not met evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Per Facility Manager, a written plan of correction will be provided to LPA Dunlap within 24 hours on how the facility will ensure care and adequate supervision to all clients in care.

investigation_findings: On October 6, 2021, at 3:12 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Jazmond Harris conducted a visit to the Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Facility Manager, Tracy Mitchell. The visit was conducted in order to provide the findings for the investigation pertaining to the listed allegation. LPA Harris initiated the investigation on August 13, 2021 at 2:02 PM. During the investigation, LPA Harris conducted interviews with Facility Manager, Staff Member, two out of six clients (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) date October 6, 2021), and additional witness. Two clients refused to be interviewed and two clients were and remained on AWOL (absent without leave) status. LPA Harris was unable to obtain contact with assigned county social workers. On August 3, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL), received information which stated facility failed to take necessary precautions to prevent the spread of Covid-19. It was reported that after clients reported symptoms and were awaiting test results and the facility allowed a visitor to the home. It was reported that the visitor was allowed access inside the home and bathroom area. It was also advised that upon entrance the visitor was not asked to sign in, report temperature, wash or sanitize hands, or wear a mask. Information obtained from

investigation_findings: On January 24, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Smith arrived at the facility and met with Stella Maris Facility Manager, LaKeicha Chaney regarding the above complaint allegation. During a Health and Safety inspection at the facility on 01/19/2022, LPA Smith observed electrical outlets in bedroom #1 that were missing covers. LPA Smith also noted that the prongs on a electrical plug appear to be burnt. During confidential interviews it was reported that when using the outlet sometimes it cause the eletricity in the home to go out or sparks can be seen. Based on LPA observations, facility is cited for Title 22 Regulations 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds which poses an immediate health, safety and/or personal rights risk to clients in care. A copy of this report along with appeals rights and LIC421FC were provided to Facility Manager, LaKeicha Chaney.
deficiency_1_description: 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The Licensee will purchase covers for all electrical outlets and will have a licensed electrician inspect the wiring in the home. Proof will be emailed to LPA Smith by 01/25/2022.

investigation_findings: On 02/16/2024 at 01:15pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sarah Lo and Cynthia Velasquez met with Brigid Osonwa, Youth Care Counselor, to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation at Stella Maris Growth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). On 08/30/2023 at 09:50 AM, LPA inspected the facilityâ€™s physical plant, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with four staff (S1-S4) and one client (C1). Needs and Services Plans and case notes were reviewed. On August 23, 2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation stating that the staff over medicated a minor (C1) while in care. Specifically, it was stated that C1 overdosed due to staff giving C1 too much medication. A confidential interview stated that the pharmacy had printed the wrong prescription label with the incorrect dosage. (continued on LIC 9099c)

(b) Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The STRTP will provide CCL with a plan to retrain all of the staff with the duty to pass out medication.  The STRTP shall include the date and time the training will take place. In addition, include how this deficiency can be avoided in the future.

investigation_findings: This report is being Amended from the original report dated 04/13/2023 to correct the violation Type and section code. On April 13, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of concluding the investigation and deliver findings on the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator, Talesha Payne and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Staff interviews revealed the food served to the clients in the STRTP is different from what is served in the cafeteria; that they follow the National School Lunch Program guidelines to provide meals to the STRTP clients; and that food purchased for the STRTP kitchen is separate from food purchased for the main cafeteria. Client interviews revealed meals were not fresh, and that they have started using their own allowance to purchase food. Based on information obtained and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC 9099 D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80076(a)(1) FOOD SERVICE.
deficiency_1_description:
80076(a)(1):In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply:
(1) All food shall be safe and of the quality and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Clients will resume dining in the cafeteria. Food for the STRTP will be purchased on weekly. Administrator will take pictures of the following: weekly menu, food served to the clients each day, and grocery receipts, and email the information to the LPA weekly for the next 30 days.

investigation_findings: On May 09, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made a follow up complaint visit to St. Anneâ€™s STRTP for the purpose of delivering findings on the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, confidential interviews were conducted, facility file, Program Statement review, and Incident Reports were reviewed. Statements were consistent that safety checks were conducted each time clients returned from unauthorized absences, school, and community passes. Statements indicated that staff reminded minors in care that anytime they left facility premises without a staff, a search of their person and belongings would be conducted upon their return to the facility. Confidential statements revealed searches were conducted on each minor in care and minors in care were instructed to pull out bra and shake, empty pockets, checking their ponytails, taking off shoes, checking hoodies, bags, strollers, and baby seats for contraband. Based on information obtained from confidential interviews and documentary evidence, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. cont on 809c
met_with: Daisy Delgado/STRTP Director of Residential Services
deficiency_1_description: 87072 (a)(10) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, and below, as applicable:  This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Facility will update Program Statement to remove blanket search policy language. Program Statement was updated to correct blanket policy of searches.

investigation_findings: On April 27, 2023 at 2:42 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of concluding the investigation and deliver findings on the above allegation. LPA met with STRTP Director, Milena Melkonyan and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Confidential interviews and records produced corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Staff interviews revealed cafeteria staff were not present at the facility to prepare breakfast and that direct care staff present at the facility did not prepare breakfast which resulting in clients in care not being served a meal. Client statements revealed that staff did not provide breakfast in a timely manner. Based on information obtained and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC 9099 D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 87072 (c) PERSONAL RIGHTS. 87022.1.
deficiency_1_description: 87072(c): The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee will empliment written procedures to ensure all meals are served to clients in a timely manner, the plan must also include which staff will be resposible for making sure the procedures are followed. The written plan must be submitted to LPA by POC due date, 05/25/2023.

investigation_findings: This report is being amended from previous report dated 07/12/2023 On July 12, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips conducted an unannounced visit to St. Anne's STRTP for the purpose of concluding the investigation and deliver findings on the above allegation. LPA met with Carlos Tobar/Quality Assurance Director and discussed the findings. During the investigation LPA Phillips interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information regarding the allegation. Evidence revealed food served to the clients was undercooked, burnt and dry, there was insufficient juice brought up for the clients and their babies, the food didnâ€™t look appealing, clients and staff would not eat the food and food served was different from the menu. Based on the preponderance of the evidence, the allegation is being substantiated. A deficiency will not be issued due to the facility being cited on 4/13/23 regarding food concerns and the facility putting a policy in place to inspect the food. This amended report supersedes the prior report dated 07/12/2023.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett made an unannounced complaint investigation at the facility and met with William Webster, Director of CQI. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings on the above allegation. During the course of the investigation LPA Hiett interviewed 4 clients and 2 staff, and reviewed records. The records and the interviews indicated that a staff member did choke the minor through the improper use of a manual restraint. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility did not properly complete comply with the client's Personal Rights. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Title 22 deficiencies were cited, and Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was left withWilliam Webster, Director of CQI.

deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Facility will provide all staff with updated training on approved manual restraint techniques. Facility will provide proof of training by 7/15/2022.

deficiency_1_description: Personnel Requirements - Prior to employment or initial presence in the facility, all employees and volunteers subject to a criminal record review shall obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by law or Department regulations.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The identified staff was not hired. The licensee understands the Guardian process and will ensure that all individuals who are subject to a criminal record review shall obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption prior to employment or intial presence in the facility.
deficiency_2_description: Personnel Records - The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. For employees that are required to be fingerprinted pursuant to Section 80019, each personnel record  shall contain documentation of either a criminal record
deficiency_2_plan_of_correction: The identified staff was not hired. The licensee will ensure that proof of a criminal record clearance or exemption is maintained in each facility employee file.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - AGAPE
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced inspection of the facility on 7/28/21 at 11:10 AM and met with staff, Megan Campagna. LPA toured the outside of the facility on this date but did not enter the facility due to COVID positive protocol. LPA attempted to interview one vocal youth about the situation but youth declined to interview with Licensing. LPA interviewed two staff persons during the inspection. LPA was informed that staff have seen signs of rodents in the house as mouse droppings were found around the canned food supply in the home and staff reported that evidence was found in one of the bathrooms in that mouse droppings were found in a bathroom drawer over a week prior to this inspection. While the staff at the facility cleaned the evidence left in the bathroom and pest control has been out and placed traps outside the home as seen by the LPA during the exterior inspection, the facility may need to do more to ensure that mice are not able to gain access to the home.
deficiency_1_description:
Buildings and Grounds. The facility shall be maintained clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. 

This was not met as evidenced by
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: While the facility already subscribes to a pest control service monthly at this location, they are planning to increase the frequency of the visits. In addition, the facility shall ensure that the pest control looks for and blocks all potential entry sites to deter additional infestations.

facility_name: SUMMITVIEW CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - SHADOW RUN
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele inspection with Anna Gleason, Chief Executive Officer on 12/4/20 to discuss the findings of the complaint allegations as stated. LPA informed Ms. Gleason that the investigation included initial tele inspection at the facility on 9/3/20 and interviews conducted with youth (C1 through C6, see LIC811 dated 12/4/20) on 9/4/20, staff were interviewed from 9/4/20 through 9/11/20. The allegation that there was a lack of supervision resulting in unauthorized activies relates to an incident where youth were provided a needle by S1 to either tattoo themselves or give a tattoo to other youth while staff were present and supervising youth. During confidential interviews, it was disclosed that S1 did provide C2 with a needle to give themselves and C1 a "stick and poke" tattoo. S1 knew at the time the needle was provided what the needle was going to be used for and S1 supervised the youth to ensure that they did not give each other piercings as well. S2 stayed inside the facility to supervise the other youth in care but allegedly knew what was happening with the other youth outside. During the interviews, it was also disclosed that C7 gave themselves a stick and poke tattoo of a smilie face on the inside of one of her fingers with the same needle.
deficiency_1_description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This standard was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Facility immediately dismissed staff persons S1 and S2. S1 was dismissed as she did provide the needle and watched youth while engaged in this activity. On June 10, 2021 the Department received information that on May 28, 2021 the facility conducted an intake interview with Youth 1 (Y1). On June 8, 2021, the authorized representative was notified that Y1 would not be accepted into the program. LPA review the facilities approved Plan of Operation which stated: â€œAfter the intake interview, our agency will communicate acceptance or rejection of the referral within five business daysâ€¦â€. investigation_findings: On June 29, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Facility Manager Grace Williams to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. In addition, LPA completed a review of the facility records. On May 13, 2021 a safety inspection was conducted by LPA Zirbes, no deficiencies were observed. On May 7, 2021, the Department received information that unknown staff members, failed to provide youth 1 (Y1) with access to a medical appointment. Confidential interviews reported Y1 had a medical appointment scheduled for April 20, 2021. Confidential interviews reported the appointment was missed due to a lack of transportation. Additional confidential interviews reported there were no problems with transportation to medical appointments. Staff reported that on April 10, 2021, Y1 made an appointment without the consent of the facility. Staff further reported that Y1 was informed, that the facility could not provide transportation to the appointment as indicated by the program statement. Staff members reported that on April 19, 2021, Y1â€™s CSW was informed that transportation was needed for the appointment on April 20, 2021.

More specifically, that facility air conditioner was not working properly (see confidential names list LIC 811 dated November 5, 2020). investigation_findings: On May 10, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez sent by certified mail the findings of the complaint to the P.O Box on file due to facility closure. On November 20, 2020, the Department received a complaint alleging: Staff are sleeping during the evening shifts, Staff failed to properly supervise minors while in care and Staff inappropriately transports minors while in care. During the investigation process, LPA Hernandez conducted confidential interviews and gather information about the allegations. S2 confirmed falling asleep while working with the clients, which was corroborated by the clients and S3. Also, C2 confirmed to have thrown water on S4's face, due to S4 sleeping during the night shift. Although S4 denied falling asleep, this was confirmed during confidential interviews. In addition, S2 confirmed transporting the clients in his personal vehicle, which was confirmed by S3 and the clients. Based on LPA interviews and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations of Neglect/Lack of supervision are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Deficiencies were cited to the facility for Neglect/Lack of supervision A copy of this report was sent by certified mail to the P.O. Box on file for the licensee's signature.
deficiency_1_description:
80078 (a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. 

This requirement is not met as evidence by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: LPA Hernandez received the Plan of Correction (POC) via email on 11/24/2020 from the administrator. The administrator will monitor and place S2 and S4 on probation and train staff to ensure these types of violations do not occur again to ensure clients are supervised at all times.

investigation_findings: On 2-10-23 11:36AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made an unannounced inspection to T&T House of Champions and met with Tracy Rawlins, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigation Branch (IB), Investigator Victoria McIntosh. During the course of the investigation, (IB) conducted interviews with staff members, clients, witnesses, and authorized representatives. IB also obtained documentation, a police report and medical records. On 10/26/22, an incident occurred at the facility between (C1) and (S1) (see LIC 811, dated 02/10/23 for confidential names). (C1) was upset with (S1) and threatened (S1) and started hitting the staff member, which resulted in (S1) stabbing (C1) in the left abdomen. The facility contacted the authorities, and (C1) was transported to the hospital by ambulance. (IB) obtained the medical records and police report. continued on LIC 9099-C

investigation_findings: Licensing Progran Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewed staff and facility manager. LPA was not able to interview current clients due to unavailability or unwillingness. However LPA did interview a former client who stated that while she was living at this location she did receive the wrong medication on one occasion due to accident, The client stated that she suffered no ill effects and is unaware of which actions the staff took after she ingested the wrong medication. Due to information obtained during the investigation process, the allegation that facility inappropriately dispensed medication is resolved as substantiated. A finding that the complaint is substantiated means that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. This LIC 9099 supercedes the substantiated LIC 9099 written on 01/08/21
deficiency_1_description: Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(11).
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a self directed corrective action plan detailing how further occurrences of this type will be prevented.

investigation_findings: This amended report supersedes report dated 08/10/2022. On August 30, 2022 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to Wayfinder Family Services TSCF for the purpose of conducting a follow up complaint investigation visit on the above allegations. LPA met with TSCF Assistance Director - Veta Talton. During the course of this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, gathered documentation, reviewed records and reports. investigation_findings: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lourey Bartolome conducted a complaint inspection for the purpose of delivering the findings for the above complaint allegation. LPA spoke with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews, review of records and review of video camera footage from the facility. The information obtained during the interviews and video footage indicated that the Group home staff did not provide any de-escalation techniques prior to the restraint of a youth, the restraint which was also done inappropriately. Type B: This poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care. Based on the LPAâ€™s observations, interviews, records review and camera footage, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegations are found to be substantiated. Facility was cited for The Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1 Articles 1 through 10. The Agency is being cited for violations of Section 87095.00(c)(1) General Provisions.
deficiency_1_description:
GENERAL PROVISIONS Short-term residential therapeutic program staff may be justified in using restraints as an
emergency intervention if all of the following conditions are met:
(1) The restraint is reasonably applied to prevent a child exhibiting assaultive behavior
from exposure to immediate injury or danger to self or others;

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: By due date, Administrator is to provide LPA with a copy of their staffing plans that indicate the facility will remain in compliance during a restraint. Administrator already provided LPA with a copy of the training that was provided to staff.

LPA spoke with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews and review of documentation. Based on interviews and documentation, staff could of prevented inappropriate sexual interaction between youth and physical altercation between . Staff did not conduct the nightly checks and staff were not supervising the clients to prevent the above allegations from happening. Therefore the above allegations are substantiated. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Facility was cited for Title 22, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision
deficiency_1_description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision	 (a)	The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This regulation was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Staff have been written up and have been retrained. LPA received copies of the write ups. By due date, Administrator is to provide proof of the training that was provided to the staff.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Slusher and Tamara Melikian conducted a follow-up complaint inspection with the above facility. Analysts met with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews with facility staff and foster youth and other interested parties as well as conducted a review of records including incident reports and police reports. The information obtained during the investigation substantiates the allegations. A review of the staff schedule notes only one staff person between 7:00 and 8:00am and only one staff member between 9:00 and 10:00 pm consistently. Interviews and staff schedule indicate other times when the facility has not met appropriate ratios. A review of needs and services plans for C1, C3 and C5 indicates a need for 1:1 Staffing. Additionally, several incident reports indicate as follow up that the facility is adding 1:1 staffing. The youth served by the facility have a high incident of suicidal ideations and attempts. Facility is not meeting the needs of these youth.
deficiency_1_description:
87065.5	Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios	(a) 	In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows:
(1) 	During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum.
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, Schedules have been updated to reflect appropriate ratios. Schedule provided to LPA on this date.

87078	Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_2_plan_of_correction:
Per Administrator, facility has fewer clients and is able to address the client needs with staff.  Additional Staff have been hired. 

Schedule given to LPA on this date.
deficiency_3_description:

(c)	Prior to the Department issuing a license, the applicant, administrator and any adult other than a client, residing in the facility shall obtain a California criminal record clearance or exemption as specified in Health and Safety Code section 1522(a)(4).  This requirment is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_3_plan_of_correction: Per Dorothy Shanklin, this was an Administrative error in which the facility thought the staff person was cleared.  This staff person is no longer employed by the facility and the faciilty will ensure all staff have appropriate clearances and associations prior to employment or client contact.
deficiency_4_description:
Personal Rights(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:

deficiency_4_plan_of_correction: Per Dorothy Shanklin, The facility has expanded services for the youth, including employing an interpreter and ensuring that C5 has full access to her iPad used for translation services.  Facility will contact the county for additional necessary ASL services.
deficiency_5_description:
87064	Administrator Qualifications and Duties		  

(a) 	In addition to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80064, the following shall apply.
(1) 	The administrator shall be on the premises for a minimum of 20 hours per week to manage and administer the short-term residential therapeutic program in compliance with applicable law and regulation. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
