deficiency_1_description:
83072(d) Personal Rights 
The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 and below, as applicable: 
(10) To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons.
(11) To be free of â€¦ actions of a punitive nature including but not limited to interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The facility will provide docuemtation of training the staff on Chidren's Personal Rights by 8/18/24.
deficiency_2_description:
80022(e)(4) Plan of Operation 
If the licensee intends to admit or care for one or more clients who rely upon others to perform all activities of daily living, the plan of operation must also include a statement that demonstrates the licensee's ability to care for these clients.  The evidence or ability may include, but not be limited to: Documentation of training the licensee and/or staff have completed specific to the needs of these clients. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_2_plan_of_correction: The facility will provide documentation of monthly staff training on implementing the consumer(s) IPP and ISP objectives in July and August by 8/18/24.

investigation_findings: During the course of the complaint investigation, all pertinent parties were interviewed. The interviews produced corroborating evidence to support the allegation. A1 confirmed that she gave C1 the wrong medications but, as soon as she realized what she had done, told C1 to spit out the pills, but C1 didn't do it and he swallowed C2's pills plus his own pills. A1 contacted the poison control center and they told her to take C1 to the hospital to make sure he didn't have a reaction due to the high dose of Seroquel that A1 gave C1. C1 was placed under observation for approximately 5 hours with blood pressure and oxygen monitors. The Dr. told A1 that C1 had metabolized the drugs. A1 did not observe other adverse side effects. In addition, confidential interviews stated that they do not know the reason why A1 was administering the medication to C1 and C2 the day of the incident, when A2 is usually the one who does. Continue on LIC9099C

investigation_findings: On Friday 1/22/21 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mariah Hawkins and Cheyenne McCambridge met with Administrator Jane Gano to deliver complaint investigation findings. Due to pandemic social distancing orders, this visit was conducted as a televisit. During the investigation, LPAs conducted confidential interviews with the administrator and resident R1's (See LIC 811, dated 1/22/21) regional center case manager (CM) and reviewed incident report and medical report documentation. Based on the confidential interviews and record review, the youth was in a car accident while being transported by a driver from a driving company hired by the youth's school. The facility did not generate an incident report with all required information to send to the youth's CM and to CCL. Instead, the facility forwarded the CM the report generated by the driving company, which did not include all of the information required by applicable regulations. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. There is one citation, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84061 Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Jane Gano, who agreed to sign and return the copy of this report sent to Administrator.

deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The facility agrees to provide an all staff training on reporting requirements that includes when to generate incident reports, including reportable incidents that occur outside of the facility, and includes the specific information required by CCL. The training plan and sign-in sheet / list of attendees will be provided to LPA

investigation_findings: On 10/15/24 at 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit at the facility in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Mariel Pablo and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, a nonverbal resident with limited mobility who requires one to one (1:1) supervision during waking hours was left unattended in their bedroom with the door closed for approximately 5 minutes. During this time, the resident sustained an arm fracture. Staff placed the resident on the hardwood floor of the bedroom, and when staff returned, they found a toy car near the resident that had not been present before. The door was closed to prevent other residents from entering the resident's bedroom. Other staff on shift were supervising the other residents in care and did not witness anyone else enter the resident's bedroom. The investigating parties believe the resident may have sustained the injury from falling on the toy car. On the basis of the resident requiring 1:1 supervision and being left unattended, LPA determined that the allegations are true.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA Jones-Steward interviewed several staff, several witnesses and the alleged victim (C1). LPA also reviewed police reports and the facility's runaway plan. LPA did not find a Special Incident Report for this incident. During the course of the investigation LPA Jones-Steward determined that the staff on duty during the incident waited for several hours after the onset of C1's crisis to contact law enforcement and paramedics. Likewise it was determined that staff are not adhereing to the facility's runaway plan. Staff often waits in excess of an hour to report missing clients even though the runaway plan indicates that missing clients will be reported to law enforcement within 30 minutes. It was also determined that the facility had no clear plans for accompanying C1 to the hospital or supervising her while she was there. Based on information found during the investigation, the above allegations are resolved as substantiated, meaning that the â€œpreponderance of the evidenceâ€ standard has been met.

investigation_findings: On March 27, 2025, at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Armstrong met Madison Pennington the Facility Manager granted access to the facility. LPA Armstrong discussed the investigative findings related to a complaint that alleged that the facility staff did not prevent altercation between youths in care. During the investigation, LPA Armstrong conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information regarding the allegations. After reviewing all the interview statements and information obtained, the allegations have been substantiated due to corroboration from the parties involved. The staff and administrator in the facility confirmed that only one staff member was present during an incident that occurred on 2/22/2025. S5 reported being left alone to handle a crisis because another staff member called off, and neither S1 nor S4 was available to provide support. Although the facility acted promptly by calling 911 when the crisis got out of hand, S5 admitted to being the only staff member in the facility with all the children. This situation presents an immediate health and safety risk for the clients in care. (Continue on LIC9099-C)
deficiency_1_description: ILS 80078 (a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.This requirement is not met as evidence by:

The POC shall include steps the licensee will follow from now on to ensure that one staff wonâ€™t left alone with the clients in care by emailing the LPA the LIC 500 and the monthly staff schedule starting April 1,2025-June 1, 2025.

investigation_findings: On March 27, 2025, at 10:30 AM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Armstrong met Madison Pennington the Facility Manager granted access to the facility. LPA Armstrong discussed the investigative findings related to a complaint that alleged that the facility staff did not ensure required staff to resident ratios were maintained. During the investigation, LPA Armstrong conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information regarding the allegations. After reviewing all the interview statements and information obtained, the allegations have been substantiated due to corroboration from the parties involved. S3 admitted once arriving at the facility S5 was there alone with the clients and this was also stated by the administrator stating the facility was out of compliance. Although the facility acted promptly by calling 911 when the crisis got out of hand, S5 admitted to being the only staff member in the facility with all the children. This situation presents an immediate health and safety risk for the clients in care. (Continue on LIC9099-C)
deficiency_1_description: ILS 84065.5 ( c) If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty child care staff shall be increased.This requirement is not met as evidence by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: A written plan of correction shall be submitted to LPA Armstrong via email Justine.armstrong@dss.ca.gov no later than 10 days. The POC shall include steps the licensee will follow from now on to ensure that one staff wonâ€™t left alone with the clients in care. Licensee will update their program statement stating when a staff calls off there will be an on call employee that will be able to fill in at the facility so the ratios will be met.

investigation_findings: On 04/16/2025 at 10:50 AM, LPA Dennis Jarmin arrived at Wauls Small Family Home to discuss the findings of a complaint investigation regarding staff failing to report incident(s) involving minor(s) and engaging in inappropriate interactions in the presence of minors. LPAs met with the licensee and explained that the investigation concluded on 03/27/2025. During the investigation, LPAs conducted interviews, reviewed records, and gathered supporting evidence. Confidential interviews and records confirmed that staff engaged in a verbal altercation on facility grounds in the presence of clients. The incident was neither documented nor reported to the Department, as required. This reflects a failure to maintain professional conduct and protect the emotional well-being of clients. Additionally, the facility failed to submit a Special Incident Report (SIR), violating mandated reporting requirements. Based on a preponderance of evidence, the allegation of Inappropriate Staff Conduct/Lack of Supervision is Substantiated. Deficiencies are cited for failure to provide proper supervision and report significant incidents in accordance with Title 22 regulations.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction:
The licensee shall submit a written statement by 05/16/2025 to dennis.jarmin@dss.ca.gov detailing how the facility will:
1. Ensure staff maintain professional conduct at all times, especially in the presence of clients.
deficiency_2_description:
Title 22, Section 80061(b)(1)(H) â€“ Reporting Requirements - Each licensee or employee of the facility shall report any unusual incident or event that threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client to the licensing agency.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_2_plan_of_correction:
The facility must also develop and implement a Staff Conduct and Incident Reporting Plan to include the following:
â€¢ Updated internal policy on professional conduct and conflict resolution
â€¢ Procedures for timely identification, documentation, and submission of SIRs to the Department

investigation_findings: On February 12, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, emailed the complaint findings to Administrator, Terrie Martinez. On September 25 2020, the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Office (RO) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: Group Counselor III, John De La Torre. The LPA reviewed the facility Plan of Operation; Facility Sketch; and Personnel Reports, Client Register, Law Enforcement Contact Reports (LIC624-LE) from September 2020 to January 2021 and Special Incident Reports dated September 10, 2021 and September 24, 2021. The investigation revealed that although the facility is in the hiring process, based upon a review of the Personnel Reports for September 2020 thru January 2021 the facility is not maintaining the six Lead Counselors and 24 Group Home Counselors as outlined in the Plan of Operation. The investigation revealed that the facility can call in extra help and staff from Kern County Department of Human Services in order to meet the staff to client ratio of 1:4. The facility trains new hires according to the Plan of Operation, but has found difficulty in maintaining new staff.
deficiency_1_description:
Plan of Operation.  The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.


This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The facility will provide CCL with documentation that the facility is low on staff and their plan to meet the requirement, along with Kern County's practices and procedures on hiring when the facility cannot meet the Plan of Operation.  The agency completed a hiring  recruitment and hired one staff with plans to hire six Group Home Counselor (GCI) I & IIs.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
investigation_findings: On June 21, 2022 at 9:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres (TSCF) and spoke with Claudia Rice, Division Director. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, a total of three (3) clients, three (3) staff, and five (5) witnesses were interviewed. Confidential interviews with staff and witness statements revealed that transportation of Client #1 (C1) to their school of origin is solely the responsibility of the Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS). Confidential interviews with witnesses reveal that once a child is placed at Five Acres TSCF, DCFS Co-Locater staff contacts the DCFS Region Worker staff to inform them of the childâ€™s need for transportation to school and the arrangements are made to transport the child to school or their school or origin by the Region Worker staff. investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an initial complaint inspection on 7/8/25 at 9:10 AM and met with Alicia Wasklewicz, Program Manager. LPA Hill discussed the complaint allegation with Ms. Wasklewicz, and it was discussed that C1 (see LIC811 dated 7/8/25) arrived at the facility on 6/11/25 and due to overcapacity, there were no bedrooms available so C1 was placed in the living room to sleep from 6/11/25 through 6/16/25. Ms. Wasklewicz did acknowledge that C1 was not provided a bedroom during these days. As a result of the complaint allegation and interview conducted with Ms. Wasklewicz, the allegation that client was not provided appropriate bedroom accommodations is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the â€œpreponderance of the evidenceâ€ standard has been met. The facility was cited for violation of Group Home Regulation, Section 84087(b)(4) Buildings and Grounds as no room commonly used for other purposes shall be used as a bedroom and it was observed that C1 slept in the living room for the days indicated. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to the facility, along with appeal rights.

deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Currently all clients are in bedrooms and are not sleeping in unauthorized areas.

facility_name: VALLEY OF THE MOON CHILDREN'S HOME
investigation_findings: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli met with Section Manager Briana Downey regarding a complaint investigation at theTemporary Shelter Care Facility. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA Bertoli inspected the facility, interviewed youth, staff, and youth's representatives, and reviewed documentation. LPA confirmed through interviews with youth that there were incidents of one staff, who is no longer at the facility, who would touch the youth inappropriately. This was also supported by interviews with staff who indicated that the reports from the youth were consistent and they felt it was valid and that the youth involved were not prone to fabrication of events. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff touched the minor inappropriately. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Title 22 deficiencies were cited and Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.
deficiency_1_description: Personal Rights 84072(d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, ... live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home. This requirement is not met, as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Facility has separated this staff person and he has not worked there since the incidents were disclosed.  Facility is doing annual Personal Rights and Trauma Informed Care training and they do daily incident reviews at the end of shifts.  POC is cleared.

investigation_findings: On April 14, 2025, at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the complaint investigation. Prior to entering the facility LPA Gray conducted a health and safety risk assessment. During the investigation, LPA Gray interviewed all available parties and reviewed documentary evidence. Statements and review of documentary evidence were consistent. Confidential statements and an internal investigation indicated that staff refused to provide care services to minors. Statements indicated that clients arrived at the facility with medical issues that required medical attention and with instruction on how to treat their medical issues. Documentary evidence indicated that staff were issued final written warnings that outlined their role expectations and that their refusal to provide care and supervision to clients was unacceptable and they were instructed to adhere to the corrective actions. Documentary evidence indicated that staff are no longer employed due to resigning from positions.
deficiency_1_description:
(a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Statements and documentary evidence indicated that due to clientâ€™s medical condition,
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction (POC) was discussed. Prior to the investigation the facility conducted an internal investigation, followed reporting protocol, and provided evidence that S2, S3, and S4 received disciplinary actions and corrective measures were applied.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewed the program director, the housing director , the nurses assigned to the client and the youth counselors assigned to child . LPA attempted on three occasions to reach the client's social worker but was unsuccessful. LPA also reviewed the email chain between Wayfinders and the Department of Children & Family services. Wayfinder staff repeatedly requested assistance from DCFS because they were not properly trained to feed Client #1 or maintain her feeding tube. The emails also indicated that the client had insufficient feeding supplies with her when she arrived on site. LPA reviewed the daily observation log for Client #1 and noted that although she was in the facility for three days, she was only given one shower and on the first day she was not fed from 3:05 AM until 1:00 PM while staff waited on authorization from nursing. The shift notes indicate that insufficient feeding supplies hampered efforts to feed C1 properly and on the day of discharge she was not fed due to a missing g-tube connection. Based on the information that was obtained, the allegations are resolved as "substantiated" meaning that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met.

Care for Clients Who Rely Upon Others to Perform All Activities of Daily Living

investigation_findings: On 10/25/24 at 9:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted a complaint investigation visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Licensee Audra Stance and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, text documentation, and facilityâ€™s plan of operation at the time, the facility was withholding allowance. Confidential interviews indicated multiple clients in care were affected simultaneously by the withholding of the allowance. In addition, text documentation and interviews indicated licensee reducing allowance and changing weekly stipends to monthly stipends. This is due to licensee not receiving funds from Eligibility due to social workers not submitting SOC 152 on youths. investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a follow-up complaint inspection with First Place for Youth and spoke with Lauren Grayman- Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, incident reports and records were reviewed, and confidential interviews were conducted. Based on interviews and record review, LPA spoke to Administrator regarding apartment and let LPA know that the apartment was put on a treatment plan when roaches were first reported but client moved out. First Place For Youth gave up the lease due to client no longer being at the unit. The agency has investigated the complaint alleging apartment has roaches and mold. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. No citations were given due to the apartment being put on a pest control treatment plan when first notified about the incident. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

On 10-5-22 12:21PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted a follow up complaint investigation at First Place For Youth and met with Chloe Whittlesey, Program Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings of the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff and clients. During confidential interviews with LPA Karkazis, it was disclosed that there was an infestation of mice in one of the apartments. It was also disclosed that the facility immediately began addressing the problem by bringing in glue traps and hiring an exterminator. A verbal and written timeline of the service was provided to LPA Karkazis, to fix the mice infestation, and relocation of clients until the rodents were gone. It was also disclosed to LPA Karkazis that a few months ago it took First Place For Youth three weeks to address a bug infestation in their apartment. Photos of rat droppings were also obtained. Based on confidential interviews, photos, and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met to determine that staff were not assisting to keep residents free of rodents. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. First Place For Youth has taken immediate steps to irradicate rodents and shall not be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Chloe Whittlesey, Program Manager.

At 11:45AM on December 1, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Schlembach and Shikya Belfield conducted an unnanounced complaint inspection at the above-listed agency. The LPAs met with Administrator Lauren Grayman and DeReassa Chambers (County Program Manager - Santa Clara County) who assisted with the visit. Program Director Rachel Carlos made herself available via telephone for the duration of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, staff and client file reviews, and review of other agency documentation it was confirmed that the agency did not ensure that all participants had safe, healthy, and comfortable homes to live in. An exit interview was conducted with Lauren Grayman, and a copy of this report, along the associated deficiency page and appeal rights was emailed to Lauren Grayman and Rachel Carlos.
deficiency_1_description: Section 86272(a)(1): Personal Rights â€“ The licensee shall ensure that each nonminor dependent is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 and the following personal rights: A nonminor dependent shall be free from corporal or unusual punishment; infliction of pain; humiliation; intimidation; ridicule; coercion; threat; physical, sexual, mental, or other abuse; or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, medication, or aids to physical functioning. (Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, subsection (a) provides in part: It is the policy of the state that all children in foster care shall have the following rights: To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where he or she is treated with respect.) This requirement was not met as evidenced by,
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to hold a program-staff training on personal rights by December 31, 2022. The curriculum materials, the length of the training, and a list of the names of the participants will be emailed to LPA Schlembach, following the training.

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson conducted a virtual complaint investigation tele-inspection with the above facility due to COVID-19 on 3/25/2021 at 2:00 PM to initiate a complaint investigation. LPA Johnson spoke with Diana MacNeil, Administrator and informed Ms.MacNeil this complaint investigation will be investigated by LPA Johnson for the allegations stated above. LPA Johnson informed Ms. MacNeil four photos were taken and provided to CCL showing overflowing waste management containers on the property. LPA Johnson showed the photos and discussed them with Ms. MacNeill. The facility has a white dumpster for green waste, 2 for recyclable waste and 3 cans for garbage. Both recyclable cans were overflowing with 3 extra bags on the ground. The likely circumstances that contributed to the overage were discussed and strategies used to deal with the occurrences. Ms. MacNeill reported the amount of facility garbage is usually maintained in the containers. Based on LPA's observation, photos, and interviews conducted, the complaint allegation is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, 80087 (a) Buildings & Grounds. Exit interview was conducted. Reports were provided via email. Facility Signature will be on hardcopy. Appeal Rights provided.
deficiency_1_description:
BUILDINGS & GROUNDS
Four photos were taken and provided on 3/22/2021 to CCL showing 2 overflowing recyclable cans and 3 additional bags on the ground of the property which exceeds waste management sanitation practices.This is not met as evidenced by
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction:
1. All staff with be retrained concerning proper waste management and containment. 
2. We will be requesting an additional recycling bin to accommodate for events or graduations that would cause need for more space to properly dispose of waste. 
3. Staff will maintain the area daily.

investigation_findings: On 02/24/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a follow up complaint investigation with The Last Resort. This LPA met with Board of Directors President Melissa Muncrief. The purpose of the follow up is to provide the outcome of the investigation. Due to restrictions of Covid-19, the followup was conducted by teleinspection with a scan of the documents to Ms. Muncrief on this date with a request for signature and a scan back on this date. Clients and staff were interviewed. In addition, documents were obtained and an inspection of the physical plant was conducted. Resident (#1) did not have the appropriate documentation for the facility to administer psychotropic medication and the required form was not used for psychotropic medication. In addition, law enforcement contacts were not properly reported to the Department. The faciliy did have a sufficient amount of qualified staff, however, they were lacking in training requirements. Based on the above, the complaint is substantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was scanned to Ms. Muncrief. Deficiency on the attached page.

investigation_findings: On 6/24/2022 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Morning Star and spoke with Administrator/Licensee Reggieanne Villar-Battung and Facility Manager Irma Battung. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, incident reports and records were reviewed, and confidential interviews were conducted. Based on interviews and record review, Morning Star conducted two sessions on August 19th and 20th for C1 in 2021. Other than that, Morning Star did not conduct any Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) sessions in the facility. ABA sessions has been taken place at C1 and C2's fathers or grandmothers house. C1 and C2 have a maximum of 15 hours of ABA a week. They are currently using 6-9 hours a week. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation, Facility is not meeting minor's medical needs is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations,Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1, Health Related Services, 80075 (a) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights prvoded and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Reggieanne Villar-Battung, Administrator/Licensee.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores arrived at the agency on 08/31/21 and met with Rene van der Meer â€“ Program Manager to deliver investigation findings for this complaint. LPA Walker-Flores conducted the complaint investigation. LPA interviewed six total clients, seven staff which included two former employees, and an Administrator. LPA interviewed staff (S1) on 05/06/21, S2 on 05/18/21, S3 on 05/25/21. Interviews were conducted with C1-C5 and administrator on 05/14/21. LPA interviewed S4-S6 and C6 on 07/20/21. LPA reviewed facility roster, staff schedule, daily activity calendars and incident reports. Complaint alleges that facility is understaffed. All six clients interviewed stated that the facility is understaffed. Consistent statements from clients indicate the clients feel that there are more serious incidents and a lack of activities, due to the facility not having enough staff. Consistent statements from staff indicate that the Agency does not provide enough staffing to meet the needs of the clients and staff are left out of ratio. Staff stated on several occasions they would be left alone to supervise a house of six clients. Both clients and staff stated they feel unsafe due to the facility being understaffed. Both clients and staff stated that incidents could be avoided if the facility were staffed properly. (continued on 9099C)

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Aleza Ruiz arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Tim Dykes, Mental Health Supervisor. LPA Aleza Ruiz conducted the complaint investigation. LPA initiated the investigation with the facility on 10/11/2024 and met with Rene Vander Meer, Administrator and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed one Program Administrator and four additional staff. LPA reviewed records including: Placement roster, maintenance records, staff roster, staff contact list and photos. Regarding the allegation the facility did not ensure laundering equipment was in good repair, three staff members denied this, two staff members agreed with this. LPA reviewed photos of the washer that showed grime inside of the washer. The facility has several washers, records indicate one washer was replaced however the washer that had been replaced was not the washer in the photo that contained grime within it . During inspection of the washer room, LPA was unable to view the inside of the washers in use and witnessed a new washer that was recently installed, this washer was also in use at the time of the inspection. Continued on 9099C
deficiency_1_description:
Title 22, Division 6 80087(a)
The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.
This regulation was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: Facility will provide LPA with a receipt showing purchase of a new washer to replace the old washer. LPA will be provided with maintenance records showing the removal date of the old washer and installation date of the new washer.

investigation_findings: This is an amended report due to LPA including information in the 9099 that did not pertain to this complaint. On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge met with Cheif Operating Officer Bryan Bowen regarding a complaint investigation at the Group Home. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed youth and staff and reviewed records. It was during these confidential interviews that it was determined the staff does currently work at the facility and does not have fingerprint clearance. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a staff member was working at the facility uncleared. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed, and Title 22 deficiencies were cited and a civil pentaly was issued. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was left at the facility.
deficiency_1_description: 80019 Criminal Record Clearance (b)The following persons are exempt from the requirement to submit fingerprints: (1) A medical professional, as defined by the Department in regulations, who holds a valid license or certification from the individual's governing California medical care regulatory entity and who is not employed, retained, or contracted by the licensee...This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The facility will submit fingerprint clearance for the employee. The staff member will also not be able to work until they are fingerprint cleared.

investigation_findings: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge met with Administrator Scott Sowle and Cheif Operating Officer Bryan Bowen regarding a complaint investigation at the Group Home. investigation_findings: On 08/11/2023 at 9:05am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility, Newport Academy Group Home, for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation: (3) Licensee does not ensure direct care staff training topics are appropriate for the client population at facility. The investigation included confidential interviews with facility and administrative staff. Per LPA request of training records, which the Licensee provided; a review of the records revealed that training topics are few and not varied, and do not meet the minimum, regulatory requirement. Based on all interviews conducted, and documents obtained, the Department has found the above allegations to be substantiated, meaning that, the preponderance of the evidence has been met. The facility is issued a citation. The following deficiency was cited [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiencies]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were provided to the licensee. The report will be emailed to Facility Administrator.

investigation_findings: On 5/3/2024 at 12:15pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the listed allegation. LPA met with Patrick Protacio, Counselor. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted nine confidential interviews. LPA reviewed the staff schedule, daily notes, staff member training, clientsâ€™ treatment plans, pertinent incident reports, contraband found inside the facility, and therapist notes. LPA observed that a magazine with adult content including lewd depictions of intercourse was retrieved from a client in care. According to record review and confidential interview, parts of another adult magazine with similar content was found in the facility. investigation_findings: On 08/11/2023 at 9:05am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility, Newport Academy Group Home, for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation: (3) Licensee does not ensure direct care staff training topics are appropriate for the client population at facility. The investigation included confidential interviews with facility and administrative staff. Per LPA request of training records, which the Licensee provided; a review of the records revealed that training topics are few and not varied, and do not meet the minimum, regulatory requirement.. Based on all interviews conducted, and documents obtained, the Department has found the above allegations to be substantiated, meaning that, the preponderance of the evidence has been met. The facility is issued a citation. The following deficiency was cited [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiencies]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were provided to the licensee. The report will be emailed to Facility Administrator.

deficiency_1_plan_of_correction:

investigation_findings: On 12/28/2023 at 9:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility, Newport Academy Group Home, for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation. investigation_findings: On 03/28/2023 at 12PM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to the facility Newport Academy Arena (5530 Johnston Rd, Pleasanton, CA) for the purpose of conducting an unannounced complaint investigation for the facility Newport Academy Paloma (37455 Palomares Rd., Castro Valley, CA). Due to recent severe weather, Newport Paloma has been closed and inspections for the facility have been conducted at Newport Arena. On 04/04/2022, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Newport Academy Paloma with three allegations: (1) Staff do not provide a safe and healthful environment for residents in care; (2) Inappropriate touching by one residents toward residents; and (3) Inappropriate sexual language used by one resident toward residents. This complaint was investigated by LPA Fremont. Based on review of facility incident reports from the month of March 2022 that reported inappropriate sexual and physical interactions between clients, and based on interview with staff, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegations (1) Staff do not provide a safe and healthful environment for residents in care; (2) Inappropriate touching by one residents toward residents; and (3) Inappropriate sexual language used by one resident toward residents are substantiated. Deficiencies were cited for the following regulations: 1. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072(d)(11) - Personal Rights 2. Title 22, Divison 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. At this time, 2 deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights Provided, and a copy of this report was emailed to Residential Supervisor Gordo Mahal, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
deficiency_1_description: 84072 Personal Rights: (d) [...] the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights (11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_1_plan_of_correction: The facility will conduct training with all staff on Personal Rights and Trauma-Informed Care, and will submit training materials and signature proof of completion for all staff no later than 11:59PM on 04/28/2023.
deficiency_2_description: 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
deficiency_2_plan_of_correction: The facility will conduct training on Providing Care and Supervision with all staff, and will submit training materials and signature proof of completion for all staff no later than 11:59PM on 04/28/2023.

investigation_findings: On today's date, at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) SIngh-Sood, and Student Assistant (SA) Selena Cook, conducted a complaint inspection to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. LPA met with Administrator, Naward Smith, who assisted with the inspection. During the complaint investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL), as well as this LPA had been aware the facility has had cameras for years that record the exterior, as well as the main areas of the home such as the living and dining areas. However, Ms. Smith informed that for the safety of the clients in care, the cameras had recently been upgraded to also record audio. Based on the following, the allegation is SUBSTANTIATED, or true. As such, deficiencies were cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80000(b), and Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with Ms. Naward. Lastly, an exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was emailed to Ms. Smith at 12:30 PM .

investigation_findings: On 6/20/2025, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood conducted an unannounced inspection to the above licensed facility. The purpose of this inspection was to deliver the finding for the above allegation. LPA met with Helena Serpa, Direct Care Staff, who assisted with the inspection. On 2/7/2025, this allegation was referred to the Department of Social Services Investigation Bureau (IB), accepted as a full investigation, and assigned to Investigator Romelia Munoz. During the course of the investigation, IB conducted confidential interviews, reviewed confidential documents, along with video footage of common areas within the facility, which was provided by the facility staff. Although the staff involved in this incident denied the allegation, there was a preponderance of evidence that IB was able to gather, and determine to be met. The client in care had bruising on her inner thighs, and had been observed on video footage, with having her hair pulled, and being called demeaning names by the staff involved. As such, the allegation of a Personal Rights violation is found to be true, and Substantiated.

Based on confidential interviews, the former resident was being switched to a nasal seizure medication for which the care team determined nursing hours would not be required. investigation_findings: On 1/9/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings for the above allegation. LPA met with Interim Administrator Kylie Leblanc and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, multiple medication errors were observed and/or reported. Staff interviews indicate there has been inconsistency in direction on medication, resulting in staff confusion, mislabeled records, and missed administration. On 12/21/22 and 12/23/22, medications were not administered to two residents who require assistance with administration of medications due to developmental disabilities. Additionally, previously on 05/29/22, medications were not administered to the same two residents. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80075 Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Interim Administrator Kylie Leblanc, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Staff informed LPA that new mattresses have been purchased, including one which has already arrived. Staff opened the package and laid out the mattress to expand to be placed in the room with the torn mattress. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84088. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rigths provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Compliance & Training Specialist Erinique Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: On 1/18/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit at the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings for an investigation of the above allegations. LPA met with House Manager April Lindsey and Compliance & Training Specialist Erinique Jones and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, staff sent a resident to school with no shoes because the resident refuses to wear them, leading to the resident sustaining injury on the foot. However, on at least one occasion, the resident was not sent with any shoes or socks, preventing later intervention by school staff to again attempt to cover resident's feet.. Staff have attempted different methods, and a note was posted for staff in the medication room directing staff to ensure shoes are worn/provided due to resident sustaining injuries. However, confidential interview with witness indicates that the resident's feet were observed in person in December 2022 to be dirty and swollen. Further, the resident has sustained multiple injuries, including scratches, bruises, and an injury to the nose, which have not been reported to the licensing agency nor authorized representative, and for which staff, including management, when interviewed, could not identify the cause of injury nor date of incidence or observation.

investigation_findings: On 3/13/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Maria Gonzvales and Administrator Vanessa Baldwin over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interview, observation, and record review, it was found that a staff member without medical certification or qualifications who was trained by another staff member without an active medical certification administered a specialized nasal rescue medication to a resident whose health care plan indicates trained staff may provide incidental assistance but that only licensed nurses may administer the medication. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met and therefore the above allegation is substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. See LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Facility Manager Maria Gonzvales, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: On 10/11/23 at 12:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy Oâ€™Connell and LPA Jhane Haynes made unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the finding. LPA Oâ€™Connell met with S1 and discussed the investigative finding. During the investigative process, LPA Oâ€™Connell conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information on the above allegation. After reviewing all the statements and the information obtained, the above allegation is supported, as the confidential interviews confirmed that C2's personal belongings were not safegaurrded according to facility policies, resulting in a technical device not being provided to C2 upon their move to a new facility. Further, record reviews reflect that inventory lists were not kept updated and did not accurately reflect client belongings. Lastly, during the initial inspection, LPA O'Connell observed the FM produce the personal belonging (specified in complaint) from the kitchen drawer in the facility, proving that the belonging was not properly safeguarded and provided to C2 upon her move to a new facility. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights were emailed to the administrator.

The purpose of the visit was to deliver findings for a complaint investigation. The Investigations Branch (IB) conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Hall opened the complaint with the facility on 06/09/2022. IB reviewed relevant records from the facility and investigative reports from Law Enforcement. IB conducted 14 confidential interviews. One staff (S2) witnessed another staff (S1) inappropriately touch a youth in care on two occasions between May and June 2022. The youth is non-verbal and unable to provide information. Additional interviews corroborated S1 exhibited inappropriate sexualized behavior toward staff at the facility and at facilities where S1 was previously employed. Based on IB and the Departmentâ€™s observations, interviews, and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. investigation_findings: On September 8, 2021 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection at the facility to deliver the finding of the allegation. LPA met with the facility representative named above. The Department received a complaint alleging that a client, who was left unsupervised, choked on food resulting in clientâ€™s death. The facility submitted an incident report informing the Department of the incident. The Departmentâ€™s Investigations Branch (IB) obtained confidential records regarding the incident. The confidential records reveal one staff was present at the facility supervising one client when the incident occurred. Staff went to the restroom and left client unsupervised for about 20 minutes. When staff exited the restroom, staff found client on the ground, unresponsive, with a laceration to the head. Staff called 911 and was instructed to perform chest compressions by the 911 operator. Staff did not start CPR prior to the arrival of Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs) Bakersfield Fire Department (BFD) found client in the corner of the room, curled up on the ground.

investigation_findings: On May 26, 2022, at 12:45pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Hernandez met with Lupe Rodriguez Facility Administrator (FA) and discussed the investigative findings. On July 8, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging Staff members' conduct were inimical to the care of group home minors. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff took clients to the home of the facility's President of the board Angelo Naemi, because he was having a party. During the investigation process and documentation review, it was confirmed that the Angelo Naemi does not have a criminal record clearance or exemption. Furthermore, it was confirmed during confidential interviews that clients were left unattended at Angelos's home. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations are unsubstantiated. If any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the findings can be changed. Continue on LIC9099-C

investigation_findings: On 06/01/2022, at 9:45 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Program Representative Selene Acosta, of Sleepy Creek to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. facility_name: SOUTH COUNTY GROUP HOMES, INC I
investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an unannounced compliant inspection at the above facility on 8/30/2022 at 10:40AM. The purpose of this inspection is to deliver the findings regarding the above complaint allegations. LPA Belfield met with Maria Gado, who assisted with the inspection. Based on confidential interviews conducted and obtained supportive documentation to include but not limited to; staff schedules, staff training records, needs and service plans, and staff phone roster. On at least six occasions the facility failed to provide sufficient staffing ratios for the clients in care. Due to the insuficient staffing ratios, there was no coverage for persons who were to receive additional staffing support. Based on obtained documentation, staff have not had sufficient training and training hours. The preponderance of the evidence has been met. Therefore, these allegations are Substantiated.

LPA Hill attempted to contact S1 but S1 did not respond to LPA Hill's calls or messages. The allegation that staff did not respond to youth in a trauma informed manner is related to an incident that occurred at the facility on 4/29/25 in which C1 incidentally walked into S1's hand while S1 was talking. Initially S1 said they were sorry but then retracted this saying they were not sorry due to C1's behaviors earlier in the day. investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection with Sunol Hills at Fremont and spoke with Adriana Elias, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During investigation, records were reviewed, facility did not ensure fingerprinting was cleared before staff started working. Based on a review of the Licensing Information System (LIS), Guardian, facility roster and facility staff schedule, it was discovered that 1 staff started working at the facility before the live scan was sent and processed. The staff hire date was on 4/5/2021. The staff live scan was cleared on 11/20/2021. The date that the staff was onsite, and working was on 10/21/2021. This meant the staff was working for a month before getting their background and fingerprints cleared. --------CONT. ON LIC9099C-----

investigation_findings: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection with Sunol Hills at Fremont and spoke with Blue Pujol, Facility Manager. Based on interviews and records review, facility was not within their program statements' ratio of 1:3 during the times of 10pm to 7 am. In February, facility was out of ratio 16 out of the 28 days. In March, the facility was out of ratio 17 out of 31 days. Facility has clients with AWOL behavior that require additional staff to follow and redirect clients back to the facility. Additionally, LPA Ng received a picture of the facilities thermostat dated January 2nd and recorded 54 degrees. LPA Ng measured the temperature in each room of the facility on 2/9/2022 and three out of six bedrooms and dining area measured below the minimum of 68 degrees F.

investigation_findings: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge initiated a complaint investigation with the Group Home and spoke with Administrator Linda Ervin.The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. Through video evidence and during staff interviews it was revealed that a staff handled minor in an inappropriate way. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff handled minor in care in a rough manner. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed, and Title 22 deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was sent to the facility.

investigation_findings: On July 15, 2021 at 1:00pm Out of State Group Home Analyst Sarah Waklee contacted the facility by telephone to deliver findings to the above complaint allegation. Analyst Walkee spoke with Regional 1 Director. Analyst Waklee conducted telephone interviews with three staff members, two youth, a San Luis Obispo Deputy Sheriff, and reviewed Tri-Counties Regional Center documentation. Based on information obtained through interviews, and documentation review there is a preponderance of evidence that staff withheld food from a child as punishment. Therefore the above allegation is substantiated. Facility cited for violation of the Interm Licensing Standards,Version 3.1, Section 87072(d)(11) To be free of phsycial, sexual, emotional, or other abuse and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercieon, threat, mental abuse or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living funcitnos of eating, sleeping or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing or aids to physical functioning.
